item.title: Chinese coast guard expels Japanese boat from Tokyo-controlled islands
item.description: China's coast guard yesterday expelled a Japanese fishing vessel that, according to Chinese authorities, had illegally entered waters near the Diaoyu islands, controlled by Japan but disputed by other countries. The Chinese Coast Guard indicated in a statement published on the WeChat platform that it “took the necessary control measures in accordance with the law”. Spokesman Liu Dejun said the Coast Guard ordered the Japanese vessel Zuiho-maru to move away from the area, reiterating that the archipelago, known as Diaoyu in China, constitutes "China's inherent territory." Liu also urged Japan to “immediately cease all infringing and provocative activities” in the area and assured that the Coast Guard will continue to carry out “law enforcement operations to defend the rights” of China. In recent years, Beijing has given its coast guard new capabilities, including the authority to detain foreign vessels suspected of illegally entering territorial waters, amid rising territorial tensions with U.S. allies such as Japan and the Philippines. The Chinese Coast Guard has also substantially strengthened operational capacity, thanks to the allocation of more ships and increased logistical support. Located in the East China Sea, about 150 kilometers northeast of Taiwan, the uninhabited Diaoyu Islands cover an area of ​​approximately seven square kilometers, and it is believed that there may be important deposits of gas or oil in the adjacent waters.

item.title: Housing for exchange | Alert for payment deadline
item.description: Macau Urban Renewal issued a warning yesterday to applicants for exchange homes in the Pearl Metropolis complex, informing them that they have until January 30th to “complete the purchase procedures, pay the price of the units” and present proof of registration proving the transaction. If they do not do so, candidates lose the ability to acquire fractions. The public capital company revealed that it will notify candidates via email and SMS to go to the Macau Renovação Urbana sales center on Avenida da Praia Grande and stressed that candidates must reserve time to complete the missing procedures within the deadline. The urban project, located in Lot P of the former Pearl Horizon site, in Areia Preta, which was named Pearl Metropolis, consists of 2,064 units. Last year, 1,932 candidates met the requirements to buy a house, but the authorities registered 47 who withdrew from the fraction selection process and five who withdrew their application.

item.title: Flu | Outbreaks in schools affect 87 students
item.description: The Health Services announced yesterday that 10 collective cases of influenza were detected in schools in Macau, affecting 87 students, 40 of whom tested positive in a rapid test for type A influenza. The educational establishment with the highest number of incidents was the Fong Chong da Taipa School, on Rua de Chaves, where 20 students were infected in three different classes. Both at the Flora Official School, in Travessa do Túnel, and at the Vocational and Technical Secondary School of the General Workers' Association, on Rua de Lei Pou Chon, each registered 10 students with the flu. The remaining schools where these cases were found were the School of the General Association of Women of Macau, the Colégio Diocesano de São José (V, Chinese Section), the Colégio Sagrado Coração Canossiano (English Section), the D. José da Costa Nunes Kindergarten (Taipa), the Choi Nong Chi Tai School, the Choi Nong Chi Tai School, the Santa Rosa de Lima College (Chinese Section) and the Talent School Attached to the Hou Secondary School. Kong. Despite indicating that some patients received medical treatment, the Health Services emphasized that the “patients' clinical conditions are considered mild and no serious cases or other complications were recorded”.

item.title: Book | “Receita di Casa” by Antonieta Manhão awarded in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Macanese chef Antonieta Manhão, better known as “Chef Neta”, has just seen her work honored with two awards in Saudi Arabia. More specifically, the book “Receita di Casa” won two awards in the international competition “Gourmand Awards Food Culture”, in the Gourmet categories and in the group of trilingual publications, Portuguese, Chinese and English, which were awarded in Riyadh. This is a book edited by Dorris Lei, from Co-Write Limited, translated by Adelaide Ferreira. Of note is the more than 1,200 works sent to this competition, with six being selected for the final of the group of recipe publications, with the aim of distinguishing “The Best Cookbooks in The World”. At the awards ceremony, 96 countries were represented. “Receita di Casa” was launched in January this year and features 19 recipes for typical Macanese dishes, namely the famous Minchi, Capela or Sopa Lacassá, among many others. “Neta” Manhão is also a professor of Macanese cuisine at the Macau Tourism University.

item.title: HIV | Macau hosts joint conference on virus and disease
item.description: An ancient global scourge is today a mere chronic disease, treatable with medication. However, the HIV virus is still present and it is with this problem in mind that Macau hosts this weekend, at the Grand Lisboa Palace, the 8th Forum on AIDS in Beijing, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan, organized by a local association The Macao AIDS Care Association is promoting, this Saturday and Sunday, the 8th Beijing, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan AIDS Forum, taking place at Lisboeta Macau, in Cotai. This is an event that aims to draw attention to a pathology that evolved into a chronic disease due to the scourge of deaths it caused in the 1980s, but which continues to be present and alert authorities around the world. According to a statement sent by the association, the aim is to “bring together renowned experts to discuss critical issues of HIV prevention, treatment and social support”. The event aims to cover topics such as “the public health strategy”, namely “the latest developments in policies and technologies related to HIV, including the application of artificial intelligence”, or even “social issues”, such as “important discussions on eliminating stigma and supporting elderly populations living with HIV”. Other topics on the agenda relate to the “local impact”, namely “Macau’s role as host and collaborator in this important inter-regional dialogue”. Fight stigma The conference's theme is “Together wih Love, Not Alone in the Fight” and has the support of entities such as The Home of Red Ribbon, Hong Kong Aids Foundation and Macau Association for Gender Diverse Community, which, as the name suggests, draws attention to gender equality. The description of the event states that “medical advances have not been accompanied by a proportionate level of understanding and social acceptance”, with “stigma, discrimination and social isolation [which are] deeply rooted” remaining” and which “continue to cause a great psychological impact and lead to systemic marginalization, preventing many people from accessing equitable care and living with dignity”. There is, therefore, a “critical gap between medical progress and the delay in social support”, which this forum aims to provide answers to. “We focus on two objectives, ‘Eliminating Stigma’ and ‘Building Robust Support Systems’, translating scientific knowledge into tangible and inclusive social practices”, it is described. One of the speakers comes from Italy, namely from the University of Modena and Reggio Emilia. Giovanni Guaraldi will speak, on the first day, about “Person-centered approach to HIV care: Why does it matter and how to make it happen?”. growing The most recent HIV data in Macau, released in November by the Health Services, speaks of a growing trend: between January and September this year, 28 new cases of HIV infection were registered, 14 of which were among residents and 14 among non-residents. In comparison, between January and September last year, nine cases had been confirmed among residents, which means that throughout this year there has been a 55.6 percent increase in new cases. In last year's statement, there was no reference to infected non-residents. “Among the new cases confirmed in Macau residents, all are male, with 50 percent aged between 18 and 39 years old and 50 percent aged 40 or over”, the authorities reported. Of these cases, 13 of the infections were contracted through homosexual or bisexual intercourse, while one of the cases indicated that it resulted from heterosexual sexual intercourse. “All new cases were referred to the Centro Hospitalar Conde de São Januário for monitoring and, currently, the treatment and control rate for Macau residents exceeds 90 percent”, it was added.

item.title: Housing | Sales and prices with annual drops in November
item.description: In the first half of November, fewer houses were sold and at cheaper prices, compared to the same period in 2024. Transactions fell 18.6 percent, while prices fell 9.1 percent. The usable area of ​​properties sold also decreased by more than 10 percent annually. The residential property market continued to fall in the first half of November. According to data released yesterday by the Financial Services Directorate, in the first half of November, 118 housing units were sold in the territory, 27 fewer compared to the same period last year, or a reduction of 18.6 percent. Statistical data based on stamp duty for the transfer of goods also reveals that the average price per square meter followed a downward trend, with a drop of 9.1 percent, to 66,315 patacas. Even the usable area of ​​sold homes decreased by 10.1 percent to 71 square meters In the period under review, the biggest drops in sales and prices occurred in Taipa, with a total of 21 houses sold, 15 fewer compared to the first half of November 2024, representing a drop of 41.7 percent. Residential property prices in Taipa also fell by 10.2 percent, reaching an average of MOP64,510 per square meter. On the peninsula, where 90 of the total 118 units were sold, transactions recorded a decrease of 11.8 percent. The price also decreased from 72,613 patacas per square meter to 66,476 patacas per square meter, that is, 8.4 percent less. In the most expensive market (Coloane) seven properties were sold in the first half of November, the same number in annual terms. However, the price per square meter fell 10 percent to 75,946 patacas. Closer in time In monthly terms, property values ​​follow the same trend, despite the greater number of sales driven by the peninsula market. In total, house sales increased in the first half of November, compared to the same period in October, by 3.5 percent, going from 114 transactions to 118, with the market “heating up” slightly on the peninsula with an increase of 9.7 percent. This is not surprising, given that the peninsula was the area of ​​Macau where prices fell the most in monthly terms: 13.4 percent. In Taipa, sales were maintained (11) and prices rose 5.5 percent, but in Coloane the monthly drop in sales was more severe (-36.4 percent), despite the drop in square meter prices of 11.3 percent. Taking the entire territory of Macau into account, prices suffered a negative monthly variation of 9.9 percent, falling from 73,632 patacas to 66,315 patacas per square meter.

item.title: Scams | Request for AI and more international cooperation
item.description: Chan Lai Kei, deputy linked to the Fujian Community, wants artificial intelligence to be able to access links received by mobile phone users via SMS, in order to alert them to fraudulent links Deputy Chan Lai Kei calls on the Government to use the most advanced technologies, such as artificial intelligence, to identify and prevent online scams. The matter was addressed through a written question from the legislator linked to the Fujian community. According to Chan, “technological advances” mean that “fraudulent schemes continue to proliferate”, despite the police in Macau having “persistently updated their anti-fraud mechanisms”. According to data from the Judiciary Police (PJ) cited by the deputy, between November 7th and midday on November 14th, authorities received complaints about 280 fraud attempts in which criminals pretended to be different customer support services and also complaints about 28 attempts in which fraudsters pretended to be police officers, Public Prosecutor's Office agents or Interior Courts. Complaints were received through applications made available by the authorities. “This indicates that specific types of fraud continue to be prevalent”, says the deputy. “Although these reports have not resulted in real losses, the number of cases indicates that anti-fraud advertising and technical interception measures need to be improved”, he highlights. Get to work In this scenario, Chan wants to know if the authorities will create a system using artificial intelligence, so that citizens can receive “instant alerts” when they receive SMS messages considered “high risk”. The legislator therefore advocates that authorities implement a system capable of detecting the content of SMS received by all citizens. The defense of the measure is justified by what the deputy considers “the recent increase in fake customer service SMS scams”, which in his opinion “indicates the need to further improve the application's proactive alert features”. As part of its defense of the measure, Chan Lai Kei points out that the “Anti-Fraud Program”, which residents can install on the Wechat platform, has blocked more than 9,000 high-risk operations since its launch in April 2024. At the same time, the deputy is concerned about fraud committed in other countries, such as Myanmar, where large fraud centers operate, often linked to mafias in mainland China. Without mentioning the countries most involved, Chan warns that part of the phenomenon is outside Macau and therefore requires greater international cooperation, despite recognizing the cooperation developed with Hong Kong and Singapore. The deputy supported by the Fujian community therefore wants to know how the authorities will detect the place of origin of the crimes and reinforce international cooperation.

item.title: Fires | Nick Lei defends strengthening security measures
item.description: Following the fire in Tai Po, Hong Kong, and inspections carried out by Macau authorities, Nick Lei asked what measures will be adopted to ensure safety, especially on construction sites Deputy Nick Lei hopes that the Government will remain alert to fire safety needs, and ensure effective supervision on construction sites. The matter was addressed by the deputy linked to the Fujian community, through a written interpellation. The position is taken following the fire in the residential complex in Tai Po, Hong Kong, which resulted in 156 deaths, according to the most recent count, at a time when victims of two residential towers still remain to be counted. The preliminary causes of the fire were related to the materials installed in the renovation work of the residential complex. Now, Nick Lei has come to recall that after the fire the authorities inspected 60 construction sites with scaffolding, so he wants to know what will be done to correct flaws that have been identified. “In response to the flaws discovered during inspections, how is a permanent review mechanism established to ensure that construction materials meet fire safety standards (…) with a view to effectively raising the level of fire safety on construction sites?”, asks the deputy. Lei also wants to know how to “completely resolve the issue of installing obstacles in corridors” used as emergency exits. More specific plans Furthermore, the deputy linked to the Fujian community argues that current relief plans must be more specific to respond to the needs of population density, types of local construction and environmental characteristics of the different areas of the territory. Nick Lei also wants the Government to clarify emergency response procedures, to guarantee the safety of the population when there are major catastrophes. Lei also points out that Macau can obtain support from neighboring areas in a timely manner, if it has plans to do so. As for advanced emergency response equipment, Nick Lei wants to know what high-tech means will be imported to assist in rescue work, with the aim of improving firefighting capacity in specific environments, such as tall and older buildings. “The Government must reinforce safety inspection in public spaces and places, particularly with regard to the preparation of fire-fighting plans in low-rise buildings in community neighborhoods and buildings that do not have an administration entity or condominiums”, he advised. Nick Lei argued that in this way “the efficiency of evacuating buildings in an emergency situation can be increased”, reads the written interpellation.

item.title: Five Year Plan | Economist highlights focus on solving internal problems
item.description: Economist Maria Fernanda Ilhéu understands that the Central Government's 15th Five-Year Plan aims to consolidate regional economic aspects and resolve “aspects of the Chinese economy that are still problematic”, such as “weak domestic demand”. The position was taken at a seminar promoted by the Chinese Embassy in Lisbon What are the objectives proposed in China's 15th Five-Year Plan, whose public consultation ended on November 14th? For economist Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, former Macau resident and president of the Friends of the New Silk Road Association (ANRS), the plan could respond to “some aspects of the Chinese economy that are still problematic, such as weak domestic demand”. The position was taken at a seminar, held recently in Lisbon and promoted by the Chinese Embassy in Portugal, entitled “Interpretation of the 15th Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social Development of China. Perspectives for Future China-Portugal Cooperation”. Maria Fernanda Ilhéu's speech, consulted by HM, was published by her on social media. For Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, “despite government stimuli, domestic consumption remains low in its contribution to GDP [Gross Domestic Product]”, and “some bottlenecks and obstacles are impeding economic flows, such as the delay in agricultural and rural modernization and the pressure on employment”. At this point, the economist highlighted the “graduates who do not find jobs that match their qualifications”, in addition to the fact that the country still hopes to achieve “per capita income growth, which is intended to be more accelerated and balanced in regions that are still very poor”. In turn, there are still “some difficulties in public services and social support”, while “the aging of the population presents challenges to economic development and the provision of services for the well-being of the population over 65 years of age”. Maria Fernanda Ilhéu cited data on this aspect, relating to 2024, when the elderly represented 14.1 percent of the population, 4.7 percent more compared to 2014. Based on the document presented by Beijing, the economist said that the 15th Five-Year Plan also intends to “project the Chinese economy towards self-sustainability and global competition”, and, in her view, the country faces “three challenges”. They are the “great volubility” which is described by Chinese authorities as “strategic opportunities that exist alongside risks and challenges, while uncertainties and unpredictable factors are growing”. A changing model Maria Fernanda Ilhéu also highlights that “China's growth model is changing, with population changes, corrections in the real estate sector and decreasing returns on investment in infrastructure, requiring new factors to maintain the pace of growth”. Furthermore, “technology has become fundamental on the stage of global competition”, something that “requires and pressures China towards self-reliant innovation and industrial resilience”. The economist does not forget the regional issues, which Macau is included in, particularly regarding the “objective for some cities and super regions” and the “dynamizing role of the Yangtze River Delta and the Guangdong-Hong Kong – Macau Greater Bay Area”. In this context, the aim is to “achieve progress in industrialization, computerization, urbanization and agricultural modernization through new forms of production, and fostering new patterns of development”. The idea is that there will be a “modernization of the industry”, in which the “frontline sectors” will be “artificial intelligence (AI), advanced robotics, quantum computing, semiconductors, biotechnologies and new generation of information and aerospace technology”. For Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, these areas are “foundational in a strategy of international competitiveness, resilience and growth multiplier effects”. The importance of Lusophony The economist also defended that the lines drawn up in the 15th Five-Year Plan point to the promotion of the Yangtze River Delta, including the province of Zhejiang, “homeland of the majority of overseas Chinese who chose Portugal to live and work”, or even, in the Greater Bay Area, which includes Macau, “one of the central vertices, where the centuries-old Portuguese presence is a strategic asset in cooperation between Portugal and China”. For her, the “priority areas of cooperation” should focus on green energy, namely battery production, green hydrogen and mobility, “sectors where China leads”. Digitalization and AI, particularly in the construction of “digital health” and “smart cities” tools, in terms of logistics and ports. Other strategic points are infrastructure, health, biotechnology and cooperation in scientific research and industrial production in AI, he pointed out. Bet on consumption According to an analysis by the China Briefing portal, linked to the consultancy Dezan Shira & Associates, China is currently in “very different conditions” compared to the last Five-Year Plan. Today the worst phase and consequent impacts of Covid-19 appear to have passed, however, there is “pressure on domestic industries” that will continue “to shape economic policy in the coming years”. Furthermore, the fact that Donald Trump is once again in the White House is highlighted, referring to the United States as “the largest individual trading partner and main economic rival”. In this way, the Five-Year Plan designed for the years 2026 to 2030 “will be drawn up with these issues in mind”, and “priorities will probably focus on improving economic resilience, including the diversification of trading partners and reducing dependence on imports” of products and materials considered “critical”. It is also intended to “stimulate domestic consumption and improve internal capabilities in key technologies”. The same analysis reflects a speech given by President Xi Jinping, in April this year, in which he points out that the 15th Five-Year Plan must “practically evaluate how changes in the international scenario affect China”, and an adjustment must be made, “optimizing the country's economic structure”. Regarding the promotion of domestic consumption, highlight is the announcement, on November 26th, of an action plan presented by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology of China, which aims, according to the state agency Xinhua, “the formation of multimillion-dollar consumer sectors in the coming years”. The use of artificial intelligence (AI) seems to be the norm, such as smart refrigerators “that can recommend a shopping list and glasses that can respond to various user commands”. Xinhua writes about the aforementioned plan that “China intends to form three massive consumption sectors, namely elderly care products, smart connected vehicles and consumer electronics, with a market scale that will reach trillions of yuan by 2027”. In addition, “ten categories of high-demand consumer goods worth 100 billion yuan (about 14 billion US dollars) will be promoted, including products for children and babies, smart wearable devices, cosmetics, fitness equipment, and food and pet products.” Double news The fourth plenary session of the 20th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, held in October, adopted recommendations for the Five-Year Plan, which focused on maintaining the “domestic demand expansion strategy” with efforts “to ensure that new demand drives new supply”, also promoting “positive interactions between consumption and investment and between supply and demand”. Not even on purpose, the China Briefing portal adds that the 15th Five-Year Plan “should dedicate significant space to the development of the ‘AI Plus’ initiative and supporting sectors, with policies aimed at promoting investment, fiscal support, talent training and public-private collaborations”. The 15th Five-Year Plan should also “define carbon emission targets and realign the decarbonization strategy”, and the country “is changing the main decarbonization strategy”, moving “from the focus on reducing total energy consumption to concentrating on reducing total carbon emissions”. It is worth highlighting the fact that the final version of the 15th Five-Year Plan will only be presented during the so-called Two Sessions of March next year, of the National People's Congress and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, when it will be adopted and implemented by the authorities in Beijing.

item.title: “Spiritual Narrative” exhibition this Thursday at Casas da Taipa
item.description: This Thursday, the exhibition “Spiritual Narrative – Annual Arts Exhibition between China and Portuguese-Speaking Countries” will be presented to the public, starting at 6:30 p.m., at the Casas da Taipa Exhibition Gallery, as part of the program of the 7th Meeting in Macau – Festival of Arts and Culture between China and Portuguese-Speaking Countries. This is an initiative organized by the Cultural Institute (IC) and brings together the work of eight artists from China and Portuguese-speaking countries, namely Cao Yu and Tong Wenmin, from Mainland China; Wong Hio Chit and Cosmo Wong from Macau, China; Carla Cabanas, from Portugal; Délio Jasse, from Angola; Eugénia Mussa, from Mozambique; and Juliana Matsumura, from Brazil. The exhibition presents works in different media, covering painting, sculpture, video and installation, revealing a mosaic of the cultural contexts of China and Portuguese-speaking Countries, “expressed through a rich artistic vocabulary”, highlights the IC, in a note. Curatorial notes To organize this exhibition and its content, the curators based themselves on “the experience of two legendary travelers from the 16th century, one from the West and the other from the East: the Portuguese Fernão Mendes Pinto and the Chinese Xu Xiake”, both of whom, according to the IC, “measured the world with their own steps, transforming their observations and travel experiences into philosophical reflections on life”. The exhibition “uses artistic creation in place of physical travel, offering visitors a visual feast through 28 pieces/sets of works in various media”. The possible visitor experience is described, which could be similar to “following in the footsteps of a traveler, starting an artistic tour of self-reflection and exploration of the world”. This exhibition can be visited until March 1st of next year, between 10am and 7pm, free of charge. During this month, guided tours will be available in Cantonese and Mandarin, respectively at 3pm and 4pm, every Saturday, Sunday and public holiday, as well as on the 23rd and 26th.

item.title: A third of EU companies in China consider diverting production in the face of restrictions
item.description: More than a third of European companies in China are considering diverting part of the supply chain outside the Asian country, to mitigate the impact of export controls implemented by Beijing. According to a survey released on Monday by the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China, 36 percent of companies are considering developing supply capacity outside China and 32 percent plan to obtain inputs from other markets, while 43 percent have not yet made a strategic decision. The survey, carried out between 6 and 24 November with responses from 131 companies, reveals that the majority have already been affected or expect to be affected by Chinese measures, which cover rare earth minerals, lithium battery technologies, super-hard materials and extraterritorial controls on products that incorporate components processed in China. According to the report, the most immediate impact is on delivery times: 40 percent of respondents indicated that approval procedures added more than two months to supply times, while another 34 percent reported delays of between one and two months. The difficulties center on the process of applying for an export license with the Chinese Ministry of Commerce. Nearly 40 percent complained about a lack of transparency, 21 percent found the requirements unclear, and 40 percent said requests exceeded the official 45-day processing limit set by authorities. Some companies have expressed concern about the amount of sensitive information they must provide, including intellectual property. Other complications The problems don't end after the license is granted: 42 percent reported additional customs delays and 26 percent said the obstacles added a week or more to the shipment of previously authorized goods. Supply disruptions are affecting both exporters with factories in China and European producers who depend on Chinese parts or equipment. The document states that 60 percent foresee “moderate or significant” interruptions if all announced controls are fully implemented, and 13 percent fear total production interruptions. Chamber President Jens Eskelund warns that Chinese authorities have “added uncertainty” to the operations of European companies, coinciding with a period of trade friction between Beijing and Brussels. The institution's vice-president, Stefan Bernhart, recommended the establishment of a “general licensing system” in the short term, which would provide “much-needed stability and predictability”. In April, Beijing imposed restrictions on several categories of rare earth elements and derivatives, which led some European companies to temporarily halt their production lines. Despite the partial suspension of certain measures following the November summit between China and the United States, part of the control regime remains active and continues to affect supply chains.

item.title: Satellite Casinos | Kam Pek closed its doors
item.description: The Kam Pek Paradise casino, linked to the concessionaire SJM Resorts, closed its doors at 11:31 pm on Monday. In a statement, the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Directorate (DICJ) considered that the closure took place “in accordance with the established procedures”. “After the closure of the Casino Kam Pek Paradise, at 11:59 pm on December 1st, the DICJ immediately suspended the operation of the tables and gaming machines, having ensured active coordination with various services, to monitor the removal of the respective premises, among other work”, was communicated by the authorities. “During the closure of the aforementioned casino, the Directorate of Labor Affairs Services sent staff to the site to provide clarifications to the workers in question, and they were provided with information on an open line for further consultation”, it was added. The number of workers affected by layoffs was not communicated by the DICJ, which also did not make reference to the number of workers who will be transferred to SJM Resorts. In July this year, when it was confirmed that the Kam Pek Paradise casino was going to close, the news caused surprise among analysts. A statement from CLSA that month indicated that the closure was unexpected, given that the casino was run at a profit.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Cui Zizhong (1574-1644), the painter from Laiyang (Shandong), who lived in Beijing near the end of the Ming dynasty, was, in the North, a notable figure in the resurgence of figure painting that in the South, with Chen Hongshou (1599-1652), led this resurgence with strange representations of human figures and their environments. Adjectives such as «bizarre», «eccentric», «peculiar» but also «archaic» were attributed to his paintings. The latter, however, already points to a common desire among literate painters: if they were anachronistic they continued to correspond to the desire to make painting a vehicle to convey elevated feelings and fluid thoughts. Cui Zizhong's figures sometimes seemed to express this effort. Looking at their disheveled clothes, some noticed how they looked like people who had just returned from sleepless nights of long conversations that didn't even allow time to rest. Other painters, in their works, followed these extravagant visions, proving that figurative meetings perhaps corresponded to authentic dialogues. Such would be the case of a literary friend of Cui Zizhong who after the age of sixty dedicated himself solely to painting at court, at the Imperial Academy of Painting in Beijing, restored in the Ming dynasty, called Wang Chongjie (1605-1667). item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description:
By Ana Cristina Alves, Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center1 The early Taoist philosophy, that of Laozi and the Book of Way and Virtue (《道德经/經》), will choose the water of the ocean and the sea as the privileged image of the Tao (道 Dào), that which cannot be said, without form, on which the universe itself and the ten thousand beings (万物 wânwù) that inhabit it depend, as well as the first principles of existence, the void (無/无 wú), the masculine yang (陽/阳 yáng) and the feminine yin (阴/隂yīn). This choice of an indigenous Chinese philosophy finds its echo in popular language and philosophy, for example in expressions such as “enormous capacity” (海量Hǎiliàng), which can have both an affective and social interpretation of portentous generosity or magnanimity, as well as a physical and concrete one, applying to someone who can ingest large quantities of alcohol. The sea is also linked to the word good and constant, for example in the “oath of eternal love as energetic as the sea and firm as the mountain”, where mountain lends added firmness to the promise (海誓山盟 or 山盟海誓Hǎishì-Shānméng or Shānméng-Hǎishì). The ocean, the sea, but also the great rivers are made up of generous water, both in popular and erudite Taoist philosophy. Here water is the figurative model of the Tao, as read in the Book of Way and Virtue and in the best sinology, which is why we recommend additional reading of Alan Watts Tao: The Watercourse Way. It is worth paying special attention to the chapters in which water appears as the closest representation of the Tao in the Book of Way and Virtue, namely: chapters 8, 14, 34, 66 and 78. In chapter 8 we are informed that the Tao is the supreme good “like water” (上善如水) (Abreu, 2014, 43), but it is not water itself. Therefore, it will be due to the similarity of functions that both are compared. Now water is generous, granting life to all beings, without establishing any distinction between them, its gift reaches even those that no one likes and I am thinking, for example, of parasites. It remains close to the earth to fertilize it, it is deep, simple, true, fair and correct and very timely, when it washes and cleans at the right time. So is the Tao. In the first verses of chapter XIV, regarding the Tao, an aquatic image appears again:
You look and you don't see, It's called Indistinct. You listen and you don't hear, It's called Silent. Touch and don't get caught, It's called Subtle. This trio is not decipherable For it merges into a unity 2 (Ribeiro, 2004, 32-33) And a little later we are told that he is nameless and uninterrupted (繩繩不可名) (Ibidem) The Tao is like an ocean, an uninterrupted and inexhaustible unity in which someone easily imagines themselves swimming in water that is neither too bright nor too dark, as would happen to Michael Saso in his 14th meditation on the Tao, in A Taoist Cookbook. with Meditations from the Laozi DaodeJing, which he called “Nadar no Tao” (Saso, 1994,47), a meditation that he accompanied by a recipe for spinach, soy paste and sesame, since the wise man is the one who “empties the mind and fills the belly” (虛其心實其復) (Ribeiro, 2004, 10-11), here one feels how the author is immersed in the great Tao, following with the current. Water can also be represented in a large river, as in chapter 34: The great Tao floods like a river, To the left, to the right, Ten thousand beings depend on him. （大道泛兮/其可左右/万物恃之而生） (Abreu, 2013, 94-95) In the same chapter we are told that the Tao not only gives life but nourishes and feeds, being an essential shelter in the return to the origins, not for death, but for eternal life diluted in the great unity, being therefore great, as big as the sea, or rather the great sea, which is the ocean. Whoever wants to be as it should be in existence or even correctly govern the world, must follow the model of the water in rivers and seas, as we read in chapter 66: Rivers and seas are greater than a hundred valleys Because they remain below them, and so they are princes, dominating waterfalls and streams. (江海所以能为百谷王者/以其善下之/故能为百故王)3 (Abreu,2013, 158-159) The wise man's behavior is distinguished by its malleability and spontaneity. He does not impose himself, which is why he is respected by everyone, only he should then govern, because he acts naturally, without oppressing, without hurting, letting everyone follow their course as freely as possible, as is reiterated in chapter 78: Nothing in the world is more malleable and flexible as for water, but in attacking what is hard and rigid nothing can surpass it and there is nothing to replace it. (天下莫柔弱於水/而攻堅強者莫之能先) (Ribeiro, 2004 160-161) Laozi's Taoist water is among the Five Chinese Elements (Water, Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal) the one that evokes great oceanic unity, source of life for everything that exists, but also of death, or rather, of return to origins and eternal life, when this image represents the philosophical principle Tao. And if water, fresh and salty, is the supreme good of the world, the Tao is the origin, the supreme good, including of Heaven. As a root or mysterious female (chap 6) it is the root of the cosmos as we know and experience it. He is a source of spiritual and material life, but so is water, since his model must be followed in all circumstances, from the material source of beings to complex human conduct. People who act correctly, and especially Taoist sages and saints, are aware of the physical and concrete model of water that helps them practice another invisible one, that of Tao. They will then be malleable and adaptable, capable of nourishing themselves from the inside and giving life to any form on the outside. You will know how to transform yourself to better nourish and vivify. The Taoist oceanic model differs from the one that inspired the Portuguese throughout history, who looked to the sea as their ocean. Taoist water is not challenging nor does it call for conquest, it does not have cables of storm or hope to bend, it does not require weapons or boats, nor maps, nor nautical instruments. It is the dominant, conquering element within all beings, who will adapt to this most malleable element, without needing to develop their inventive spirit. The philosophy it leads to does not ask for vigilance or a critical spirit, but adaptation to the world as it is and generosity to accept it with a minimum of suffering and a maximum of joy. item.title: Julie Oyang
item.description: Interview with James Yanzhao Xing, Chinese private collector living in Xi'an, specializing in Ancient Jade (Archaic Jade) Four years ago, in 2021, James inherited more than 300 pieces of antiques from his elderly father. The family heritage dates back to the Song dynasty (10th-13th centuries) and the collection includes exquisite jade items, porcelain, bronze wares, incense burners and high-value jewelry from various periods. During the turbulent war years, these treasures were buried in a hole in the backyard for decades. Now, through their interdisciplinary curatorial project, they are about to enter a dynamic dialogue with the worlds of fashion, art and sport. Joy: How did you feel when you received the family inheritance? I was completely surprised! My brothers and I had no idea that our family had such things. We were ignorant about our family history. Joy: Tell me about your family history. James: Our original surname was Zhao and we belonged to the imperial family of the Song dynasty. Our roots are in the heart of Chinese civilization. Chinese history has been complicated and turbulent, and my family has failed to preserve the details of our specific ups and downs. All I know is that in 1931, to escape the Japanese occupation, my grandmother took my father and other family members and together they walked to Chongqing in the south. My father was still a boy. To survive and take better care of her son and family, my grandmother decided to remarry into a local clan called the Xing. The Xing family accepted the proposal, as long as my grandmother paid them 300 taels of silver, a significant amount in wartime China. That's how we changed our imperial surname Zhao to Xing. After remarrying, my grandmother asked my father to dig a hole in the yard. That's where the family heirloom was stored, until my father decided to pass it on to me. My father didn't want to divide the collection between my brothers, as he knew I was the only one who could appreciate its true value. To repay my father's appreciation for me, I immediately gave my private collection a name: Jade Ambience, 琼华幸境 in Chinese. Joy: Why that name? James: I feel like I've always been lucky in life, like I've always been protected by some supernatural force with which I could cure strange illnesses and save people. You know, I love helping people and I can't stand seeing sadness and injustice in the world. Since he was a child, he saved lives during the annual floods of the Yangtze River in Chongqing. I didn't fear for my own life, because I knew I was protected. Will it be a gift? I would like to believe so. I even abandoned my career as a successful businessman and decided I wanted to be a soldier, so I could actually contribute to my country instead of earning a lot of money. I even turned down an opportunity to go to the USA and run a company there. That was in 1989. My experiences in the army made me stronger, both physically and mentally. I value life's experiences because they make me understand the human world better and give me positive energy to appreciate each day. In some inexplicable way, I attribute all of this to the jade items in my collection (laughs). JOy: In fact, Chinese people believe that jade stone radiates positive energy. Since ancient times, jade has been associated with protective power, healing power and immortality. What is the true value of your collection, in your opinion? As I said, jade has a very special place in Chinese culture. Jade symbolizes moral integrity and virtue, which is the stone's central symbolic value. Confucianism inextricably linked jade to the ideal of the “exemplary person” (junzi 君子), who should embody the virtues reflected in the physical qualities of jade, including benevolence, righteousness, wisdom, courage (“It is better to be a broken jade than an intact tile”) and purity. Jade served as a material expression of authority and was made into ritual objects used to communicate with divine forces and symbolized imperial power—most notably through the legendary Imperial Seal made of jade. For ordinary Chinese people, jade offers protection and good luck and has long been considered a talisman against evil forces. Jade carvings also carry auspicious meanings: bats for blessings, peaches for longevity, and fish for abundance. In ancient belief systems, jade was believed to preserve the body and soul after death. This concept found its ultimate expression in the jade burial suits of the Han dynasty, intricately assembled from thousands of pieces of jade to ensure immortality. Jade was also seen as the essence of the cosmos—a fusion of the vital energies of heaven and earth. The Chinese language is rich in jade-related expressions that convey admiration and virtue! Therefore, jade items are timeless symbols of love, symbolizing lasting and sincere affection. Today, jade remains a precious heirloom, a solid investment, and a powerful emblem of cultural identity — connecting contemporary Chinese to our heritage. In this way, jade contains old and new life! Jade is not just a precious stone full of vitality. It is a cultural landmark — a bridge between old China and new China. Joy: What do you want to do with your collection? James: Right now, I'm planning to organize a traveling exhibition in Beijing, Shanghai and maybe Macau. As I said before, jade is full of vitality. Jade is a bridge between ancient China and modern China. So I don't want to limit my collection to the usual antique circles. I'm thinking about doing cross exhibitions with fashion, art and sport. I want jade to have a lively dialogue with contemporary, young and modern Chinese audiences!

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Cui Zizhong (1574-1644), the painter from Laiyang (Shandong), who lived in Beijing near the end of the Ming dynasty, was, in the North, a notable figure in the resurgence of figure painting that in the South, with Chen Hongshou (1599-1652), led this resurgence with strange representations of human figures and their environments. Adjectives such as «bizarre», «eccentric», «peculiar» but also «archaic» were attributed to his paintings. The latter, however, already points to a common desire among literate painters: if they were anachronistic they continued to correspond to the desire to make painting a vehicle to convey elevated feelings and fluid thoughts. Cui Zizhong's figures sometimes seemed to express this effort. Looking at their disheveled clothes, some noticed how they looked like people who had just returned from sleepless nights of long conversations that didn't even allow time to rest. Other painters, in their works, followed these extravagant visions, proving that figurative meetings perhaps corresponded to authentic dialogues. Such would be the case of a literary friend of Cui Zizhong who after the age of sixty dedicated himself solely to painting at court, at the Imperial Academy of Painting in Beijing, restored in the Ming dynasty, called Wang Chongjie (1605-1667). For the portrait that Wang Chongjie made in the summer of 1657 of the Suzhou painter, Wang Jian (1598-1677), which is in the Kaikodo Art Gallery, in Hawaii (horizontal scroll, ink and color on silk, 43.3 x174 cm), other important authors who participated in these dialogues contributed: Wang Wu (1632-90), according to a colophone, created the landscape around the subject, with a river where two ducks swim, and next to the painting, the celebrated painter Wu Weiye (1609-71), who lived through the dynastic transition with sorrow, wrote a poem. Wang Chongjie, in making Wang Jian's portrait, would seem to be making a synthesis of the state of art in his time. Not only was he the grandson of the famous and venerated painter Wang Shizhen (1526-90), but the careful treatment of the shadows on his face may indicate the appropriation of a new way of doing things resulting from contact with European painters who were at the court at the end of the Ming. In an album that shows literati next to watercourses (paint and color on silk, 25.5 x 31.3 cm, at the Angewandte kunst Museum in Frankfurt), when there are mountains they are only schematic. If, as Confucius said, mountains please the heart and flowing waters please thoughts, one can deduce that it was this flowing water that inspired them. And what were these dialogues about in the midst of pristine nature, Zhang Yanyuan in the 19th century. IX, writing about the edifying character of painting, said: «it is a means through which events are preserved, in such a way that they serve as models (for the virtuous) and warnings (for the wrong path)».

item.title: Five Year Plan | Economist highlights focus on solving internal problems
item.description: Economist Maria Fernanda Ilhéu understands that the Central Government's 15th Five-Year Plan aims to consolidate regional economic aspects and resolve “aspects of the Chinese economy that are still problematic”, such as “weak domestic demand”. The position was taken at a seminar promoted by the Chinese Embassy in Lisbon What are the objectives proposed in China's 15th Five-Year Plan, whose public consultation ended on November 14th? For economist Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, former Macau resident and president of the Friends of the New Silk Road Association (ANRS), the plan could respond to “some aspects of the Chinese economy that are still problematic, such as weak domestic demand”. The position was taken at a seminar, held recently in Lisbon and promoted by the Chinese Embassy in Portugal, entitled “Interpretation of the 15th Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social Development of China. Perspectives for Future China-Portugal Cooperation”. Maria Fernanda Ilhéu's speech, consulted by HM, was published by her on social media. For Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, “despite government stimuli, domestic consumption remains low in its contribution to GDP [Gross Domestic Product]”, and “some bottlenecks and obstacles are impeding economic flows, such as the delay in agricultural and rural modernization and the pressure on employment”. At this point, the economist highlighted the “graduates who do not find jobs that match their qualifications”, in addition to the fact that the country still hopes to achieve “per capita income growth, which is intended to be more accelerated and balanced in regions that are still very poor”. In turn, there are still “some difficulties in public services and social support”, while “the aging of the population presents challenges to economic development and the provision of services for the well-being of the population over 65 years of age”. Maria Fernanda Ilhéu cited data on this aspect, relating to 2024, when the elderly represented 14.1 percent of the population, 4.7 percent more compared to 2014. Based on the document presented by Beijing, the economist said that the 15th Five-Year Plan also intends to “project the Chinese economy towards self-sustainability and global competition”, and, in her view, the country faces “three challenges”. They are the “great volubility” which is described by Chinese authorities as “strategic opportunities that exist alongside risks and challenges, while uncertainties and unpredictable factors are growing”. A changing model Maria Fernanda Ilhéu also highlights that “China's growth model is changing, with population changes, corrections in the real estate sector and decreasing returns on investment in infrastructure, requiring new factors to maintain the pace of growth”. Furthermore, “technology has become fundamental on the stage of global competition”, something that “requires and pressures China towards self-reliant innovation and industrial resilience”. The economist does not forget the regional issues, which Macau is included in, particularly regarding the “objective for some cities and super regions” and the “dynamizing role of the Yangtze River Delta and the Guangdong-Hong Kong – Macau Greater Bay Area”. In this context, the aim is to “achieve progress in industrialization, computerization, urbanization and agricultural modernization through new forms of production, and fostering new patterns of development”. The idea is that there will be a “modernization of the industry”, in which the “frontline sectors” will be “artificial intelligence (AI), advanced robotics, quantum computing, semiconductors, biotechnologies and new generation of information and aerospace technology”. For Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, these areas are “foundational in a strategy of international competitiveness, resilience and growth multiplier effects”. The importance of Lusophony The economist also defended that the lines drawn up in the 15th Five-Year Plan point to the promotion of the Yangtze River Delta, including the province of Zhejiang, “homeland of the majority of overseas Chinese who chose Portugal to live and work”, or even, in the Greater Bay Area, which includes Macau, “one of the central vertices, where the centuries-old Portuguese presence is a strategic asset in cooperation between Portugal and China”. For her, the “priority areas of cooperation” should focus on green energy, namely battery production, green hydrogen and mobility, “sectors where China leads”. Digitalization and AI, particularly in the construction of “digital health” and “smart cities” tools, in terms of logistics and ports. Other strategic points are infrastructure, health, biotechnology and cooperation in scientific research and industrial production in AI, he pointed out. Bet on consumption According to an analysis by the China Briefing portal, linked to the consultancy Dezan Shira & Associates, China is currently in “very different conditions” compared to the last Five-Year Plan. Today the worst phase and consequent impacts of Covid-19 appear to have passed, however, there is “pressure on domestic industries” that will continue “to shape economic policy in the coming years”. Furthermore, the fact that Donald Trump is once again in the White House is highlighted, referring to the United States as “the largest individual trading partner and main economic rival”. In this way, the Five-Year Plan designed for the years 2026 to 2030 “will be drawn up with these issues in mind”, and “priorities will probably focus on improving economic resilience, including the diversification of trading partners and reducing dependence on imports” of products and materials considered “critical”. It is also intended to “stimulate domestic consumption and improve internal capabilities in key technologies”. The same analysis reflects a speech given by President Xi Jinping, in April this year, in which he points out that the 15th Five-Year Plan must “practically evaluate how changes in the international scenario affect China”, and an adjustment must be made, “optimizing the country's economic structure”. Regarding the promotion of domestic consumption, highlight is the announcement, on November 26th, of an action plan presented by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology of China, which aims, according to the state agency Xinhua, “the formation of multimillion-dollar consumer sectors in the coming years”. The use of artificial intelligence (AI) seems to be the norm, such as smart refrigerators “that can recommend a shopping list and glasses that can respond to various user commands”. Xinhua writes about the aforementioned plan that “China intends to form three massive consumption sectors, namely elderly care products, smart connected vehicles and consumer electronics, with a market scale that will reach trillions of yuan by 2027”. In addition, “ten categories of high-demand consumer goods worth 100 billion yuan (about 14 billion US dollars) will be promoted, including products for children and babies, smart wearable devices, cosmetics, fitness equipment, and food and pet products.” Double news The fourth plenary session of the 20th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, held in October, adopted recommendations for the Five-Year Plan, which focused on maintaining the “domestic demand expansion strategy” with efforts “to ensure that new demand drives new supply”, also promoting “positive interactions between consumption and investment and between supply and demand”. Not even on purpose, the China Briefing portal adds that the 15th Five-Year Plan “should dedicate significant space to the development of the ‘AI Plus’ initiative and supporting sectors, with policies aimed at promoting investment, fiscal support, talent training and public-private collaborations”. The 15th Five-Year Plan should also “define carbon emission targets and realign the decarbonization strategy”, and the country “is changing the main decarbonization strategy”, moving “from the focus on reducing total energy consumption to concentrating on reducing total carbon emissions”. It is worth highlighting the fact that the final version of the 15th Five-Year Plan will only be presented during the so-called Two Sessions of March next year, of the National People's Congress and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, when it will be adopted and implemented by the authorities in Beijing.

item.title: What is known about the fire that killed 151 people in Hong Kong
item.description: Hong Kong continued today to count the victims of the fire that devastated a residential complex on Wednesday, the most serious in decades, with at least 151 dead. Authorities in the neighboring Chinese special administrative region of Macau detained 11 people on suspicion of negligence, but the cause of the fire has not yet been determined. Here is what is known about the tragedy, according to the news agency France-Presse (AFP): What happened? The fire alarm was raised at 2:50 pm on Wednesday. The fire hit a real estate complex with 1,984 homes and eight towers of 31 floors each, called Wang Fuk Court, located in Tai Po, in the New Territories, in the north of Hong Kong. The complex, opened in 1983, was undergoing renovation work, but continued to be occupied by around four thousand people who lived there. Immense flames spread extremely quickly between the buildings, which were surrounded by bamboo scaffolding and protective nets. Hundreds of firefighters were mobilized to provide assistance and extinguish the fire. Firefighters only declared the end of operations against the fire this morning (Friday). How many victims? The most recent provisional balance this afternoon was 128 dead [151 is the most recent number], of which 89 had not yet been identified, according to Hong Kong's security chief, Chris Tang. More than a hundred people were still missing at the same time. There were also 79 injured, 11 of which were in critical condition. Family members toured hospitals and morgues looking for victims. It is the deadliest building fire worldwide since 1980, excluding fires in nightclubs, prisons or shopping centers, according to research in the disaster database at the University of Leuven (Belgium). It is also the most serious in Hong Kong since 1948. It is still unknown to what extent the balance could increase due to the number of people about whom there is still no news. Among the missing people, there are 19 Filipino and 11 Indonesian domestic workers, according to data from the Mission for Migrant Workers organization cited by the local newspaper South China Morning Post (SCMP). Firefighters finished their inspection of all homes today, Friday. What caused the tragedy? The initial causes of the fire have not been rigorously established. The security chief admitted that the investigation could take three or four weeks. Based on preliminary findings, Tang said that the fire started in the lower parts of the shipyard's nets that protected against dust and falling objects. The spread of the flames, according to Tang, was favored by the use of bamboo for scaffolding, common in Hong Kong, and flammable materials such as foam panels that protected the windows. Hong Kong fire chief Andy Yeung also corroborated what many witnesses interviewed by AFP said. “We found that the alarm systems in the eight buildings were not working properly,” he said. Who is responsible? The anti-corruption commission announced today the arrest of seven men and one woman, aged between 40 and 63. These are two people responsible for the project office that prepared the renovation, two construction managers, three scaffolding subcontractors and an intermediary. The police had already announced the arrest of three suspects for “gross negligence” after the discovery of flammable materials abandoned during work, which allowed the fire to “spread quickly” due to the strong wind. The exact level of involvement of the suspects in starting the fire is unclear. Authorities ordered the inspection of all public housing complexes undergoing major renovations, according to the SCMP newspaper. What is the fire risk in Hong Kong? Hong Kong, a special administrative region of China with 7.5 million inhabitants, is one of the most densely populated places in the world, which increases the risk of urban disasters. The average population density is more than 7,100 inhabitants per square kilometer, with vast steep and unbuildable areas. In urbanized areas, population density is up to three times higher, a world record. This financial center, where space is limited and real estate prices are among the highest in the world, is famous for the skyscrapers surrounding the bay. The last few decades have been marked by the construction of a profusion of residential towers that can have more than 50 floors. Most of the new construction projects have taken place in the mainland of the green New Territories region, where the Tai Po neighborhood is located. Hong Kong has 569 buildings over 150 meters tall, the highest number in the world, according to data from the specialized international NGO CTBUH (Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat).

item.title: Hong Kong | Deadliest fire since 1918 leads to investigation
item.description: There have been 128 deaths and 200 people missing in what was the biggest fire in the history of Hong Kong, in the New Territories. Authorities have, however, moved towards an anti-corruption investigation given the scale of the incident in Tai Po. The Lusa agency reports the despair of many families The tragedy is far from abating in Hong Kong. The fire that occurred this Wednesday in the Tai Po area, in the New Territories, in a complex of buildings under construction, is already considered one of the largest in the history of the territory and the victims are still being counted – at the time of writing this edition there were 55 dead and 250 people missing. Today, Friday, the numbers rose to 128 dead and 200 missing. Yesterday, at the end of the day, the fire was gradually coming under control, with another 55 survivors being rescued. According to a report from the Lusa agency, the families of those missing remained in a feeling of despair yesterday, given the lack of answers. “Did you see this girl?” a mother asks the Lusa journalist in Cantonese, before switching to English. “Did you see my daughter or the ‘helper’?” he says, using the expression used in Hong Kong for domestic workers. The woman, surnamed Cheng, waves a piece of paper on which she has printed a photograph of her five-year-old daughter, Hannah Cheng, and a copy of the work permit of the maid, Indonesian Maryan. The family lived in Wang Tai House, part of the Wang Fuk Court residential complex that burned down. A spokeswoman for the Indonesian consulate in Hong Kong confirmed to the South China Morning Post that the dead included two Indonesian maids. "I haven't seen them since the fire started. Please, have you seen them?", pleads Cheng to everyone he meets at the entrance to Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole, the hospital located closest to the social housing complex, in Tai Po. The fire department said it had already managed to contact several of the 279 people who were initially listed as missing. The temperature “is very high and there are floors where we cannot contact the people who called for help, but we will continue to try”, assured the deputy director of the fire department, Derek Armstrong Chan. A post was circulating on social media from another mother, desperate for not being able to contact her in-laws, who were taking care of her six-month-old daughter, in Wang Fuk Court. "Almost 24 hours have passed [since the last contact] (…) My daughter needs to be breastfed otherwise she will die. Can anyone tell me if she was saved or not?", wrote Winnie Hui. This is already the deadliest fire since 1918, when Hong Kong was still a British colony. That year, a fire caused the collapse of the main grandstand at the Happy Valley racecourse, causing more than 600 deaths. More than 700 firefighters are involved in fighting the flames, in addition to rescue teams and police. Population helps As the hours passed, support from the population began to arrive, both in terms of physical and financial presence, at various shelters for the homeless. Serena, 16, was carrying a box of bottled water to deliver to a secondary school in Tai Po, converted into one of the temporary shelters for those affected by the fire. In addition to the 900 residents of the Wang Fuk Court residential complex, authorities ordered residents of the nearby Kwong Fuk Estate to evacuate their homes as a precaution. “This is my school, but we don't have classes today because of the fire”, explains the young woman to Lusa, who joined several colleagues to buy and donate supplies, including cookies and instant pasta. The school is just over two kilometers from the residential complex that burned down. On the second day, columns of smoke continued to rise into the sky, with the smell of burning in the air. “Everyone knows someone who lived in Wang Fuk”, highlights Serena. “We never thought this could happen here”, he adds. But it is not only in Tai Po, located closer to the border with the metropolis of Shenzhen than to the center of Hong Kong, that the population has mobilized to help. An elderly woman came from Tuen Mun, 30 kilometers away, with blankets and clothes. “It’s not enough for someone who lost everything they had”, laments the resident, surnamed Fong. The social neighborhood, built in the 1980s, is made up of eight towers with nearly 30 floors and a total of 1,984 apartments, where around four thousand people lived. According to the local press, the fire also led many people to try to donate blood, running out of appointments in the center of Causeway Bay yesterday. Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Government created a fund this Thursday with 300 million Hong Kong dollars for the victims. At a press conference, postponed twice, the Chief Executive, John Lee Ka-chiu, said that the fund, created at the state-owned Bank of China, began accepting donations from 7pm. John Lee also announced that the Government would distribute, throughout the day, 10 thousand Hong Kong dollars to each family affected by the fire in the Wang Fuk Court social housing complex. Ongoing investigations The scale of the tragedy has already led Hong Kong authorities to move forward with an anti-corruption investigation. Hong Kong's Independent Anti-Corruption Commission has set up “a working group to launch a full investigation into possible corruption in the major Wang Fuk Court renovation project in Tai Po.” In a statement, the commission justified the decision with “the immense public interest involved”. There are now three working groups: one to investigate the fire, another to deal with emergency donation resources and one for the relocation of affected families. Meanwhile, police arrested three men on suspicion of involuntary manslaughter after discovering flammable materials left during maintenance work that led to the fire spreading quickly through the bamboo floors. John Lee, Chief Executive of the HKSAR, said the Department of Home Affairs and Youth has reserved 1,000 apartments in youth hostels and hotels for affected residents to stay for a maximum period of two weeks. They will then be moved to 1,800 subsidized apartments reserved for them to settle in temporarily, he added. The official also indicated that the Government is preparing a list of goods that Hong Kong will request from China's central government, including unmanned aircraft ('drones') for inspections and materials for laboratory tests. Meanwhile, inspections are also being carried out at all real estate complexes that are undergoing major works. “The Government ordered the inspection of all real estate complexes in the city that are undergoing major renovations, to check the safety of scaffolding and construction materials,” said John Lee Ka-chiu in a message published on the social network Facebook. The complex of eight 31-storey buildings was undergoing facade renovations. Campaign suspended The leader of the Hong Kong Government admitted yesterday that the elections for the Legislative Council of Hong Kong, scheduled for December 7, could be postponed. “We will carry out a thorough analysis and make a decision within a few days, based on the overall interests of Hong Kong,” said John Lee Ka-chiu, after an emergency meeting with heads of various government departments. The Chief Executive added that the debates between candidates for the Legislative Council of Hong Kong that were scheduled for Thursday and today have been postponed, with no new date set. The remaining election campaign activities were also suspended, John Lee told journalists. "The Government is committed to dealing with this major disaster. Our priority now is to fight the fire", highlighted the leader. "The top priority is to extinguish the fire and rescue the trapped residents. The second task is to treat the injured, the third is to deal with the consequences, and then we will carry out a thorough investigation," Lee added. "As for other matters, we will decide what to do in a few days, after we coordinate our work," said the government leader. Leaders react Xi Jinping, Chinese President, yesterday expressed condolences for the victims of the fire, calling for “intense rescue efforts to minimize losses”, reported the Xinhua agency. The President also declared that he gave great importance to the accident, having immediately requested permanent updates on the work of the rescue team. Xi Jinping instructed the director of the Central Government Liaison Office in Hong Kong to convey condolences. Another political leader who also spoke out about the tragedy was the Prime Minister of Timor-Leste, Xanana Gusmão. He referred to the death of the 128 people as “tragic” and “deeply painful”. “Our hearts are with the families and friends of all those who lost their lives, as well as with those who remain missing”, he highlighted, in a press release. Xanana Gusmão also paid tribute to the “extraordinary courage of firefighters, first responders and all those who work tirelessly in rescue and recovery operations”.

item.title: OECD | World economy expected to slow to 2.9% in 2026
item.description: The OECD predicts that global economic growth will slow down in 2026, falling from 3.2 percent this year to 2.9 percent next year, with economic activity facing “fragile prospects”, associated with the impact of tariffs on global trade. In the Economic Perspectives report, released yesterday, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) points to a moderation in the trajectory of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) globally, with growth slowing from 3.3 percent recorded in 2024 to 3.2 percent in 2025 and to 2.9 percent in 2026, followed by a “small recovery” to 3.1 percent in 2027. “Growth is expected to slow down during the second half of this year [2025], as the anticipation of activity unfolds and higher effective customs duties on imports to the United States and China are reflected in company costs and final product prices, harming investment and trade growth”, describes the organization. “The projections are based on the technical assumption that the bilateral tariffs announced in mid-November will be maintained for the rest of the projection period, despite ongoing legal challenges in the United States”, he highlights. In the introduction to the report, OECD Secretary-General Mathias Cormann highlights that “the global economy has proven resilient this year, despite concerns about a more pronounced slowdown following the increase in trade barriers and significant political uncertainty”. However, it warns that the increase in customs duties should “gradually lead to higher prices, reducing the growth of household consumption and business investment”. “These prospects remain fragile”, warns the organization’s top official, stressing that if there is an increase in tariffs, this movement is expected to cause “significant damage to supply chains and global production” and there is a risk that high asset valuations, made “based on optimistic expectations of corporate profits” driven by Artificial Intelligence (AI), will lead to “potentially abrupt price corrections”. Asia on the rise In the document, the OECD notes that “high geopolitical and political uncertainty will also continue to weigh on domestic demand in many economies”, with emerging Asian economies expected to continue to be “responsible for the majority of global growth”. For the United States of America, the OECD predicts GDP growth to be “2.0 percent in 2025, 1.7 percent in 2026 and 1.9 percent in 2027”. China is expected to grow 5.0 percent in 2025, 4.4 percent in 2026 and 4.3 percent in 2027. In the second world economy, says the organization, “the end of the anticipation of exports, the imposition of higher customs duties on exports to the United States, the continued adjustment in the real estate sector and the weakening of budgetary support are expected to reduce growth”. Eurozone growth “is expected to slow slightly, from 1.3 percent in 2025 to 1.2 percent in 2026, before increasing to 1.4 percent in 2027, with increased trade frictions being offset by improved financial conditions, continued capital spending from Recovery and Resilience Mechanism funds, and the resilience of labor markets,” says the OECD.

item.title: East Timor | April Revolution left “difficult memories”
item.description: Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, researcher at the University of Coimbra, addresses, in a study, the experiences of the Timorese during the period of the 25th of April Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, a researcher at the Center for Social Sciences at the University of Coimbra, considered that the April revolution in Timor-Leste left “difficult memories” and that reconciliation is fundamental for “national cohesion”. “When we talk about the 25th of April in Timor, we know that we are talking about difficult memories that have left marks to this day due to the internal conflict and the violation of human rights during the occupation”, Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, who is currently carrying out a study on that period in the country, told Lusa. Marisa Ramos Gonçalves is also a member of the International Advisory Board of the National Chega Center (in Timor-Leste), which, among other activities, documents the history of the conflict in Timor-Leste between 1974 and 1999. The researcher explained to Lusa that the objective is to understand the other side of the story “based on the experiences of the Timorese of the 25th of April and this period of transition, which gives rise to a proclamation of independence, but which is very short compared to the occupation”. “This collective memory of the Timorese is inseparable, both from the internal conflict and from the human tragedy that is the Indonesian invasion and occupation”, highlighted Marisa Ramos Gonçalves. The unilateral proclamation of Timor-Leste's independence, on November 28, 1975, came after a period marked by clashes between the East Timorese and already under the shadow of the possibility of occupation of the territory by Indonesia, which came to fruition on December 7, 1975. Asked about reconciliation between East Timorese, the researcher said that the “issue has been on the table”. "It is necessary to achieve reconciliation between Timorese who were on opposite sides during the civil conflict with different options for the future of Timor. At the time, UDT wanted an association with Portugal for a few more years before independence, Fretilin wanted immediate independence, and Apodeti, which wanted integration into Indonesia and they are all Timorese", he stated. According to Marisa Gonçalves, the National Chega Center wants “this to start being on the table, because it has not been easy until now for Timorese who suffered torture or were persecuted during the period of internal conflict to speak openly”. "But we are already beginning to see this possibility when talking about violence and torture, which existed for a very short period in 1975, but which left strong marks. There is also a reconciliation at the level of political leadership that is yet to be achieved and I think this is also complicated. It is a reconciliation of the entire society", stated Marisa Ramos Gonçalves. Larger opening Considering reconciliation between Timorese people as fundamental for social cohesion, the researcher highlights, on the other hand, that the new generations formed in the Indonesian period and the younger ones “are completely prepared for this reconciliation”. “They are not so tied to previous conflicts and they really want to reconcile and, therefore, I think they are already looking at that future, they already think that all people are part of the Timorese Nation, including the Timorese who are in West Timor”, where there is a community of around 80,000 people, he highlighted. "It is also important that the older generation reconciles, especially because it is still a generation, the so-called generation of 75, that continues in power. It would also be interesting for them to take the initiative to get closer", he added. Regarding the study she is carrying out, Marisa Ramos Gonçalves said that there is a lack of historical research in Timor-Leste and that it is good to understand the expectations that people had not only in relation to the 25th of April, but also in relation to the political transition. “It means knowing the narratives, the experiences, the memories of Timorese people of various geographic origins, professional occupations and party affiliations about the same historical moment”, he explained, highlighting that reconciliation is also achieved through the writing of history.

item.title: November 25th | Manuel Geraldes remembers “moment of betrayal”
item.description: Portugal marked the 50th anniversary of November 25, 1975 yesterday with a military parade and a solemn session in the Assembly of the Republic, amidst controversies and political readings from right to left. Manuel Geraldes, a former soldier based in Macau, remembers the moment he was arrested at RTP For Manuel Geraldes, if happiness had a date it would be April 25, 1974, along with the day his daughter was born. But it was in connection with the 50th anniversary of November 25, 1975, an attempted coup d'état and one of the stages of the revolutionary process that began with the overthrow of the dictatorship in Portugal on April 25, 1974, that we spoke with the former soldier. Based in Macau since the 1980s, Manuel Geraldes was arrested at RTP on November 25, 1975, but, as one of the youngest captains of April, he was involved in the revolution since its beginning, starting with the so-called captains' movement in 1973. To HM, he remembers the 25th of November as “a very sad moment, of betrayal by comrades, revolt, a horrible moment, especially compared to one of the happiest days of my life, together with the birth of my daughter, which was the 25th of April”, taking into account the military plans planned for that day, which took a different turn.
