Manuel Geraldes worked at RTP when the station was controlled by one of the military factions that carried out the 25th of November. Control of RTP, at the Lumiar studios in Lisbon, included the intervention of figures such as Manuel Duran Clemente, then linked to the military extreme left of the 5th Division. "When we talk about the 25th of November we have to talk about a day of betrayal. Those who were betrayed were the soldiers who remained faithful to their ideas of the 25th of April and who swore to comply with it, and which we were fulfilling. There was a group of soldiers who, forgetting their condition, and I'm talking more about permanent staff officers, made that day of shame for any self-respecting officer." Manuel Geraldes had been at RTP for about a year and was “caught in that trap”. I went to meet my comrades at the television news management office and it was there that we were caught by Captain Duran Clemente”, he tells HM. “I can talk about those who were closest to me, and who were at RTP that day”, he began by saying. "Those who were on the 25th of April and arrested me, as they arrested six other officers, all of them 'dangerous fascists, reactionaries'. Also arrested that day was a man who was a great revolutionary, and who, still as a student at the military academy, studying at Técnico, committed the noble gesture of leaving the armed forces of the fascist regime to emigrate to northern Europe. The 'powerful' Marques, who had been in the Beja coup, and who was arrested, and managed to go into exile in Brazil. Captain Canavilhas, a ‘dangerous’ man who had been on the 25th of April and who was there providing a service to the Republic at RTP as an electrical engineer.” Duran Clemente appeared at RTP's facilities to control broadcasts, prohibit the dissemination of information from the Presidency of the Republic, since Costa Gomes was President at the time, and let messages from rebels linked to a faction of the movement pass through. The station's board of directors was detained for several hours. His live images are known on RTP, reading a statement, when he was suddenly interrupted and replaced in the broadcast by the film “The Man from the Diner’s Club”. This is because the winning faction of the 25 de Novembro movement had taken control of events from the RTP studios in Porto. Speaking to the newspaper Público, Duran Clemente also speaks of November 25th as “a betrayal of April 25th, in the way it has been interpreted and was interpreted, to the extent that it interrupted the natural course of a revolution that is never a natural path”. Duran Clemente also speaks, in the same interview, of the “fantasy story of a civil war” that many believe was about to happen in Portugal on that date. He also says “he did not commit any crime”. For Manuel Geraldes, these moments of detention “were indescribable, unbelievable, forgettable”. When he left the RTP studios, Manuel Geraldes went home to his wife, “trying to rest and try to forget the enormous sadness that was that scene”, with “the soldiers he had commanded on April 25, 1974, observing that absurd arrest that Duran Clemente made of us”. The culmination of tensions The 25th of November was an attempted coup d'état in which military personnel linked to the extreme left took several strategic points, especially in Lisbon, which led the country to enter a state of siege. But the moderates won and the country entered a calmer phase, especially after the new Constitution of 1976. It was a culmination of the so-called “Hot Summer”, or the months of the PREC – Revolutionary Period in Progress, marked by nationalizations of banks and companies, the Agrarian Reform process, organization of workers committees, attacks on the headquarters of the Portuguese Communist Party and various actions connoted with both the extreme left and the far right. Manuel Geraldes recalls that “the situation was complex and was not exactly what we had imagined” with the 25th of April. “We had designed other scenarios than that, but with great camaraderie.” Even so, the former soldier highlights the “stability and credibility” that Portugal gained after November 25, 1975. However, he does not agree with the fact that the Portuguese authorities are currently celebrating this date. "There is definitely a political component and, for me, it makes absolutely no sense. We shouldn't forget the past to correct any mistakes that were made, but celebrating a sad day makes no sense at all. We must remember." Regarding the important and decisive figures in resolving the 25th of November, Manuel Geraldes highlights “general Costa Gomes, who experienced such vast violence, Sousa e Castro and others who had consensus and managed to bring the vast majority of the armed forces to reason”. Mário Soares, as leader of the Socialist Party, “also had [importance]” to stop the movement, especially because “he had positions close to the so-called ‘Group of Nine’, the moderate members of the Coordinating Commission of the Armed Forces Movement”. Manuel Geraldes also remembers a day when the factions were ruled by “military against military”, and when “the homeland was put at risk”, in a scenario “very, very close to civil war”. Yesterday morning, a military ceremony took place promoted by the Armed Forces, at Praça do Comércio, in Lisbon, presided over by the President of the Republic, Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa. There was also a formal session in the Assembly of the Republic. Vasco Lourenço: “A coup d’état was not on the ground” In addition to the official ceremonies of the 25th of November 1975, there have been several exhibitions, lectures and conferences that celebrate all stages of the revolution of the 25th of April 1974. One of them took place on Tuesday, the seminar “25th of November – 50 years later”, at the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, where one of the central figures of the 25th of November and the entire April revolution, Vasco Lourenço, remembered the day. "It is clear that, after all this time, we cannot say that a coup d'état was on the ground. But I challenge anyone who is capable of saying that, at that time, given what was happening, we did not look at it as if a coup d'état were actually taking place." After several military movements, in which the paratrooper forces retreated, the episodes of November 25th resulted in three deaths, all military personnel, “at the beginning of November 27th”, recalled Vasco Lourenço. The role of women Another figure who participated in the debate was doctor Isabel do Carmo, who at the time of November 25th was linked to the COPCON group – Continent Operational Command, led by the now deceased Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho. Isabel do Carmo argued that “what happened after the 25th of April was the existence of a space of people, organizations and political protagonists, in which there were clearly two trends”, marked by “those who wanted to lead a revolutionary movement to de facto socialism, and those who wanted a liberal democracy with an economy regulated by a market”. "The 25th of April was, and for many people of my generation, the best times of my life. I hear many people say this, particularly women, who until then were discreet. What happened after [the 25th of April] were the public sessions, freedom of the press, the total change in the environment in schools, there was a great transformation in the country", concluded Isabel do Carmo.

item.title: Timorese women victims of sexual violence during the war demand an end to discrimination
item.description: Reporting by Domingos Freitas, from the Lusa agency The Pirilampo association, which represents women victims of sexual violence between 1974 and 1999, demands that the Timorese State supports them, after years of discrimination by society and their families. "We continue to fight alone because we were victims in the past, not of our own free will. We have suffered the consequences of this country's politics since 1974, because we wanted self-determination. Because of these political decisions, we, women, were the target of many sexual violations", Maria Isabel da Silva, president of Pirilampo, told Lusa, as part of the 50th anniversary of the unilateral declaration of independence and Indonesian occupation. Maria Isabel da Silva accused the Timorese State of not having granted them recognition that could help them recover their courage and dignity. "We created Pirilampo because we know that we are not minor survivors. We are survivors of sexual violence that occurred during the war, between 1974 and 1999. We want to recover dignity, because many face stigma in their communities and even within their own families", explained Maria Isabel da Silva. The president of Pirilampo explained that the organization's mission is to support women survivors of sexual violence through social, legal and economic assistance so that they become strong and independent citizens. The association also defends the rights of victims and survivors who remain without a voice, so that they can obtain recognition and attention from the State or Government. Maria Isabel da Silva clarified that Pirilampo's vision is to contribute to ensuring that Timorese society never again allows anyone to be a victim of serious human rights violations, especially sexual violence, including harassment, abuse, rape or forced marriage. The president of Pirilampo also regretted that cultural aspects discriminate against women who became pregnant or had children by unidentified men. "Sometimes they are considered prostitutes, remnants of the Indonesian military. These are insults that have been directed at us for a long time," he said. With support from the Chega Ba Ita Association (ACBIT) and Asia Justice and Rights (AJAR), several victims participated in various activities and, on October 22, 2022, these organizations helped them create the Klibur Survivor Feto Firefly 1974-1999, to alleviate the suffering and difficulties faced. Pirilampo has already registered 455 women survivors of sexual violence, of which 87 gave birth to children resulting from these violations. To this day, those children, often called “war children”, face a very difficult life, due to discrimination by their families, society and, above all, in the public administration. "They call them children of unknown fathers, children of bush men, of militia. This greatly affects their self-esteem and many refuse to go to school", warned the president. Maria Isabel Silva explains that many of these young people are also unable to obtain basic documents, such as baptism certificates from the Church or State documents. They live in remote areas, depend on agriculture and do not have adequate access to health and education. The president called on the Government to pay attention and recognize these people like any other citizen, so that their children can also live in freedom and equality. "We are alive. We don't ask for anything, we don't ask for money. The money from the State is not enough to pay for our dignity. We lost our bodies, we carry pain and trauma. We just want to recover our complete being. We don't ask for money", said an emotional Maria Isabel Silva. There is still discrimination Fernanda Guterres and Maria Gusmão were born after their mothers were raped by Indonesian soldiers during the occupation of Timor-Leste, and to this day they continue to face discrimination in their country. The two carry the stigma of being “war children”, a name given to people who were born to women who were raped between 1974 and 1999, during the conflict between various Timorese factions and during the Indonesian occupation. "I don't feel free, because I continue to face discrimination from society. Colleagues say words to me that hurt me, and I myself am afraid of making friends because of the harsh words they say to me", Fernanda Guterres, who works at the non-governmental organization ACBIT, which supports, with Asia Justice and Rights (AJAR), the "children of war" and women victims of sexual violence during the occupation to overcome the difficulties and traumas that marked their lives, told Lusa. “I only feel a little freedom when I participate in oratory sessions or in training given by the sisters, which encourage young people to face reality”, he highlighted. The report by the Commission for Reception, Truth and Reconciliation (CAVR), released 20 years ago, and which collected testimonies from hundreds of victims of sexual violence, states that the majority was committed by the Indonesian occupation forces. "We are Children of War because our mothers were forced and impregnated by other men during the occupation. Otherwise, the invaders would have killed the entire family. To save their own lives, many Timorese women suffered sexual violence", explained Fernanda Guterres. As a consequence of this forced rape, “war children” continue to be targets of insults and stigma. “You have no father”, “you are the son of the enemy” or “son of a militia”, are some of the insults that those women continue to hear. When she was little, Fernanda Guterres' mother told her that her father was alive, but she never met him. She later discovered that it didn't exist, but her mother never explicitly admitted it. "I asked about my mother and father many times. My mother always said 'your father is there', and said not to believe if someone said otherwise. But I never met him. In the end, I realized that I didn't have a father", he said. Fernanda Guterres also remembers, with sadness, the attempts of sexual violence by members of the community, solely due to her mother's past. "The family and also some neighbors tried to abuse me. When I was an adult, I stopped keeping quiet and asked my family to face anyone who tried to harm me", said the 28-year-old. Today, Fernanda has her own family, with three children, and said she has found a partner who fully supports her. "I met my husband thanks to God's plan. He knew about my mother's past and his whole family knew too, but they never discriminated against me. They always welcomed me. My husband supports me, gives me courage. The past is behind us. Now we look to the future and our children. That's what gives me strength", she stated. "We live a simple life. We don't have formal jobs, but we always maintain respect and mutual understanding. When a problem arises at home, we talk and look for a solution together," he said. Fernanda Guterres managed to obtain documents from the Church or State, thanks to the support of people who helped her regularize everything. Maria Gusmão also acknowledged that her mother was a victim of sexual violence by Indonesian soldiers. "When I was little, in primary school and pre-secondary school, I suffered discrimination due to the conflict my mother faced. They said I was the daughter of the militia, the daughter of the enemy. I heard this with my own ears", said the young woman from Covalima. He also remembers that some members of his community even banned children from playing with him. Later, at university and even within his family, he continued to face discrimination. Despite this, Maria Robinson appealed to other young women not to lose their will to fight, nor their hope, even in the face of discrimination, highlighting that the State must dignify women who have been victims of sexual violence and also their children. Maria Robinson was able to obtain documents because her stepfather agreed to put her name on the birth certificates. When asked about her feeling of freedom, she replied that she just feels “a little free”, highlighting that she still faces discrimination, stigma and injustice today. “From the family, to society, to the community and even to our own State”, said the 25-year-old. Maria Robinson recently completed her degree at the University of Peace (UNPAZ) and also works at the non-governmental organization ACBIT. On November 28, Timor-Leste marks 50 years since the unilateral declaration of independence and Indonesian occupation, on December 7, 1975. The restoration of independence took place on May 20, 2002, after a referendum for self-determination was held on August 30, 1999.

item.title: Scams | Request for AI and more international cooperation
item.description: Chan Lai Kei, deputy linked to the Fujian Community, wants artificial intelligence to be able to access links received by mobile phone users via SMS, in order to alert them to fraudulent links Deputy Chan Lai Kei calls on the Government to use the most advanced technologies, such as artificial intelligence, to identify and prevent online scams. The matter was addressed through a written question from the legislator linked to the Fujian community. According to Chan, “technological advances” mean that “fraudulent schemes continue to proliferate”, despite the police in Macau having “persistently updated their anti-fraud mechanisms”. According to data from the Judiciary Police (PJ) cited by the deputy, between November 7th and midday on November 14th, authorities received complaints about 280 fraud attempts in which criminals pretended to be different customer support services and also complaints about 28 attempts in which fraudsters pretended to be police officers, Public Prosecutor's Office agents or Interior Courts. Complaints were received through applications made available by the authorities. “This indicates that specific types of fraud continue to be prevalent”, says the deputy. “Although these reports have not resulted in real losses, the number of cases indicates that anti-fraud advertising and technical interception measures need to be improved”, he highlights. Get to work In this scenario, Chan wants to know if the authorities will create a system using artificial intelligence, so that citizens can receive “instant alerts” when they receive SMS messages considered “high risk”. The legislator therefore advocates that authorities implement a system capable of detecting the content of SMS received by all citizens. The defense of the measure is justified by what the deputy considers “the recent increase in fake customer service SMS scams”, which in his opinion “indicates the need to further improve the application's proactive alert features”. As part of its defense of the measure, Chan Lai Kei points out that the “Anti-Fraud Program”, which residents can install on the Wechat platform, has blocked more than 9,000 high-risk operations since its launch in April 2024. At the same time, the deputy is concerned about fraud committed in other countries, such as Myanmar, where large fraud centers operate, often linked to mafias in mainland China. Without mentioning the countries most involved, Chan warns that part of the phenomenon is outside Macau and therefore requires greater international cooperation, despite recognizing the cooperation developed with Hong Kong and Singapore. The deputy supported by the Fujian community therefore wants to know how the authorities will detect the place of origin of the crimes and reinforce international cooperation.

item.title: Housing for exchange | Alert for payment deadline
item.description: Macau Urban Renewal issued a warning yesterday to applicants for exchange homes in the Pearl Metropolis complex, informing them that they have until January 30th to “complete the purchase procedures, pay the price of the units” and present proof of registration proving the transaction. If they do not do so, candidates lose the ability to acquire fractions. The public capital company revealed that it will notify candidates via email and SMS to go to the Macau Renovação Urbana sales center on Avenida da Praia Grande and stressed that candidates must reserve time to complete the missing procedures within the deadline. The urban project, located in Lot P of the former Pearl Horizon site, in Areia Preta, which was named Pearl Metropolis, consists of 2,064 units. Last year, 1,932 candidates met the requirements to buy a house, but the authorities registered 47 who withdrew from the fraction selection process and five who withdrew their application.

item.title: Fires | Nick Lei defends strengthening security measures
item.description: Following the fire in Tai Po, Hong Kong, and inspections carried out by Macau authorities, Nick Lei asked what measures will be adopted to ensure safety, especially on construction sites Deputy Nick Lei hopes that the Government will remain alert to fire safety needs, and ensure effective supervision on construction sites. The matter was addressed by the deputy linked to the Fujian community, through a written interpellation. The position is taken following the fire in the residential complex in Tai Po, Hong Kong, which resulted in 156 deaths, according to the most recent count, at a time when victims of two residential towers still remain to be counted. The preliminary causes of the fire were related to the materials installed in the renovation work of the residential complex. Now, Nick Lei has come to recall that after the fire the authorities inspected 60 construction sites with scaffolding, so he wants to know what will be done to correct flaws that have been identified. “In response to the flaws discovered during inspections, how is a permanent review mechanism established to ensure that construction materials meet fire safety standards (…) with a view to effectively raising the level of fire safety on construction sites?”, asks the deputy. Lei also wants to know how to “completely resolve the issue of installing obstacles in corridors” used as emergency exits. More specific plans Furthermore, the deputy linked to the Fujian community argues that current relief plans must be more specific to respond to the needs of population density, types of local construction and environmental characteristics of the different areas of the territory. Nick Lei also wants the Government to clarify emergency response procedures, to guarantee the safety of the population when there are major catastrophes. Lei also points out that Macau can obtain support from neighboring areas in a timely manner, if it has plans to do so. As for advanced emergency response equipment, Nick Lei wants to know what high-tech means will be imported to assist in rescue work, with the aim of improving firefighting capacity in specific environments, such as tall and older buildings. “The Government must reinforce safety inspection in public spaces and places, particularly with regard to the preparation of fire-fighting plans in low-rise buildings in community neighborhoods and buildings that do not have an administration entity or condominiums”, he advised. Nick Lei argued that in this way “the efficiency of evacuating buildings in an emergency situation can be increased”, reads the written interpellation.

item.title: Taiwan | Proposed law targets Macau residents
item.description: Representatives of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) of Taiwan, Wang Ting-yu and Wang Yi-chuan, delivered a proposal to change the lobbying law to the Taiwanese Parliament, to punish individuals from the Interior, Hong Kong and Macau involved in this practice. The measure was presented through a statement and aims to change the law known as anti-infiltration by external agents. According to Wang Ting-yu's post on his official Facebook, although the current law already prohibits the act of lobbying by individuals, groups, entities or agents of Mainland Hong Kong and Macau in Taiwan, the law does not have any punishment, and is therefore considered inconsequential. The amendments propose a maximum fine of up to five million Taiwan dollars for each infraction, corresponding to around 1.2 million patacas.

item.title: Traffic | Deputy Leong Sun Iok defends fewer zebra crossings on roads
item.description: Deputy Leong Sun Iok, linked to the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau (FAOM), defends a reduction in the number of zebra crossings to cross roads. The position was taken through a written interpellation, in which the deputy complains that traffic faces too many constraints. From Leong's perspective, pedestrian crossings are installed with “considerable frequency”, which means that there are “multiple crossings in the same section, with extremely short distance intervals”. “For vehicles, these frequent stops and starts significantly reduce average speeds on the roads and cause localized traffic congestion, negatively affecting the general flow of the road network”, he explained. “How will the authorities find a balance between the needs of pedestrian crossings and the efficiency of traffic on the road network when reviewing and optimizing existing crossings?”, he asked. Furthermore, the deputy wants to know if the authorities will consider allowing cars to cross red lights to turn left, as happens in other countries. Thus, although there was a red light for those who wanted to go straight ahead or turn right on a street, there would always be the possibility of turning left, because a yellow traffic light would be shown. “Could the authorities explore the possibility of allowing left turns during yellow lights while the traffic lights are red?” he asked.

item.title: Maternity leave | Extended Employer Subsidy
item.description: The Government will extend for another year, until the end of 2026, the period for granting the supplementary subsidy to employers for remuneration paid during maternity leave, the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL) said yesterday. The subsidy began to be distributed after the legal review that extended maternity leave in May 2020 from 56 to 70 days, and would have a maximum limit of 14 additional days of basic pay. The plan was presented as a measure to be applied during a transitional period, “allowing employers to adapt, gradually, to the economic expenses caused by the increase in the number of days of maternity leave”, according to the authorities' explanation at the time. The so-called transition period ended on May 25, 2023, but the subsidy remained. The new extension will last until December 31, 2026, extending the deadline established by administrative regulation in force since August 26 of this year. Therefore, employers who pay maternity leave to resident workers who give birth by December 31, 2026, may request DSAL for a maximum benefit equivalent to 14 days of basic pay for the workers in question. The subsidy plan, presented as part of a package of measures to encourage births, is limited to companies with fewer than 100 employees. Deputy Wong Kit Cheng has argued that the subsidy plan should become permanent and extended to companies with more than a hundred workers.

item.title: IC | Merger with ID does not yet have a detailed plan
item.description: The president of the Cultural Institute (IC), Deland Leong Wai Man, stated that she is “preparing, in an orderly manner, the work for the combination of services” for the merger with the Sports Institute (ID) and the Culture Development Fund. Despite the “orderly manner”, the person in charge confessed that there are still no detailed plans to organize the aggregation of services, but assured that she maintains close communication with the approximately one thousand employees of the services involved. According to the newspaper Ou Mun, Deland Leong Wai Man hopes that the combination of entities will result in a synergistic effect known as “one plus one is more than two”, and stressed that the merger of the three departments will not affect the organization of cultural and sporting events next year. During the presentation of the Lines of Government Action, the Secretary for Administration and Justice Wong Sio Chak indicated that the Directorate of Administration and Public Service Services has completed the plan for the organic restructuring of the administrative machinery. The restructuring will cover several key departments, including the reorganization of the Government Headquarters Support Services, the Institute for Municipal Affairs and the Public Works Services Directorate, among others. The merger between the IC, the ID and the Cultural Industries Fund is part of the administrative reform of the Government of Sam Hou Fai.

item.title: Lessons from the Hong Kong tragedy
item.description: The devastating fire at Hung Fook Court in Tai Po, Hong Kong, broke out in seven or eight buildings. Maintenance work was taking place in these buildings and the contractors used highly flammable expansive foam to seal windows and the scaffolding used was made of bamboo, which allowed the fire to spread quickly after it started in one of the buildings. Strong winds and dry weather caused the flames to intensify, which subsequently affected the entire housing block. The fire alarms did not go off, contributing to the tragedy. Around 48 hours after the accident, the Hong Kong Government had practically extinguished the fire. With the help of the Central Government, which sent substantial resources to Hong Kong, and numerous companies that donated money and supplies, the needs were met, allowing the victims to have temporary respite. At the time of writing this article, the Hong Kong Government has just announced that there have been 146 deaths, 79 injured and 40 missing. Among the dead is a heroic firefighter who died fighting the flames. Before we continue our analysis, let us observe a minute of silence for those who lost their lives and pray for the survivors, hoping that they can soon overcome their difficulties. We also express our highest respect to all the workers and volunteers who participated in the rescue operations, praising their courage and dedication in the face of adversity. In addition to caring for the victims, the Hong Kong Government also quickly sought to identify those responsible for the accident. For example, the person responsible for maintaining the Hung Fook Court was arrested and is suspected of involuntary manslaughter. The Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) also ordered the arrest of individuals suspected of corruption. The Hong Kong Government immediately carried out surprise inspections of all protective nets used in building maintenance to ensure they met fire safety standards. The insurers working with the building maintenance companies also publicly stated that they had activated emergency mechanisms and would provide adequate compensation in accordance with the contracts concluded. In Hong Kong, some people suggested that maintenance companies should use metal scaffolding instead of bamboo scaffolding in the future. How will the victims deal with the consequences of this disaster? Firstly, the injured must receive immediate treatment. Secondly, they should immediately contact the families to let them know they are safe. We saw many people on television worried about their families, crying and waiting for news. Sending them a message to reassure them is essential. Thirdly, they will have to solve the accommodation problem. If they have another place to live or if they can stay with family or friends, they will need to continue these steps. It is not known when they will be able to return home. If they have no solution, they will have to join the Hong Kong Government's temporary accommodation program. Fourth, assuming the government inspection finds the house is still habitable, should the owners renovate it? Hung Fook Court opened in 1983, more than 40 years ago, and repair work had already begun. This devastating fire accelerated the devaluation of the property. Homeowners should consider whether it is worth making large investments in renovation, given the future value of the homes and the likelihood of them being sold successfully. In addition to the different reactions of the Hong Kong Government, the public and the victims, this devastating accident has, in fact, raised other issues that concern society. First, Hong Kong is by nature a city with a high cost of living. A worker who manages to buy a house with the salary he earns during his working life achieves a significant feat. After two or three decades of paying the mortgage, the building has become worn out and needs major work. At that point, owners need to make large investments in maintenance, making the house and the problems it raises seem like a bottomless pit, a black hole impossible to fill. The relationship between homeowners and their homes is reminiscent of the title of a television series – “property slaves.” Second, following this rare accident, contractors will be more careful about the materials they use. Insurers will also be more careful when entering into contracts with maintenance companies and will impose more stringent requirements. This means that insurance premiums may increase. Homeowners who purchased home and fire insurance may also see their premiums change. All of these factors will fall on home owners, meaning they will bear more expenses. For owners who are still working, this situation is compounded by additional charges. What about retired owners? They may have set up a fund for maintenance before retirement, but with their financial situation after retirement, they may no longer be able to cover these expenses. This should be an issue for all homeowners who were not directly affected by the fire and potential homebuyers to consider. Although properties in Hong Kong are valuable, they also give rise to many problems. This devastating accident brought new perspectives to the Hong Kong Government, society, victims and potential homebuyers. Let us hope that these new ideas benefit Hong Kong society and prevent similar tragedies. Legal Consultant of the Association for the Promotion of Jazz in Macau Associate Professor of the Faculty of Management Sciences of the Macau Polytechnic University

item.title: Celebrations pleased some fascists
item.description: More than 50 years ago, the Portuguese people, including the “snitches” of PIDE/DGS, took to the streets to celebrate the greatest gift a people can have: freedom. A military coup had ended a political dictatorship of more than 40 years. The military of the Armed Forces Movement (MFA) had managed to overthrow an oppressive regime that spent years arresting and deporting those who defended freedom, democracy, socialism and communism. The times following the military coup were turbulent because we soon realized that these soldiers also had their political options and were also beginning to play into the hands of this or that political party. Mário Soares and Álvaro Cunhal returned from exile and on the first May 1st the party was thunderous and with a popular union never seen before. As time went by, we saw that the divergences between the MFA military, supported by certain parties, bordered on radicalism. On September 28, 1974, we witnessed an attempted coup d'état carried out by conservative sectors, led by the President of the Republic, General António de Spínola and where the so-called “silent majority” prevailed at the time, which aimed to halt the democratic process, but, essentially, control decisions on decolonization. The left-wing sector of the MFA managed to ban a demonstration in support of Spínola and we remember that barricades were placed at the entrances to Lisbon in order to prevent the entry of Spínola's supporters. As a result, several organizers of the demonstration were arrested, General Spínola resigned as President of the Republic and the event marked the defeat of the attempt to turn to the right and the strengthening of the MFA's control over the revolutionary process. First important note: never in more than 50 years of democracy have left-wing democrats celebrated the victory of September 28, 1974. On March 11, 1975, we personally witnessed another attempted coup d'état, this time, commanded by General António de Spínola against the government of the time supported by the left-wing MFA military. The attempt began with the bombing of the Light Artillery Regiment No. 1 (RAL 1) and a soldier who was lying in one of the barracks was killed. The RTP archives must contain images of the piercing of the roof and the blood on the bed and floor of the barracks. RAL 1 was surrounded by paratroopers, assigned to Spínola, and negotiations lasted almost the entire day. The attempt would fail due to the lack of popular support for Spínola and due to the resistance that was registered by the RAL 1 military and many people. The failure of the coup attempt would lead to Spínola's flight to Spain and then to Brazil. Second important note: left-wing democrats in more than 50 years of democracy have never celebrated victory over the attempt to interrupt the revolutionary process. The summer that followed was very “hot” with several disputes within the MFA and with right-wing parties intensifying their confrontation with the Communist Party and other radical left parties. Everything would end on November 25, 1975. On that day, the left-wing MFA military occupied RTP and Captain Duran Clemente, while speaking directly at the public television studios, was interrupted from one moment to the next and the broadcast began to be directed from the studios in Porto. Simultaneously at the Military Police barracks, the soldiers on duty there commanded by Major Tomé found themselves confronted by military commandos from the right wing of the MFA, commanded by Captain Jaime Neves and Major Ramalho Eanes. The shooting was a reality. Two military commandos and others from the Military Police died. At the Belém Palace, where the President of the Republic, General Costa Gomes, resided, calls were made for the arrest of the 25th of April strategist, Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, and the illegalization of the Communist Party. At the end of the afternoon, with the Commando troops controlling all operations in their favor, an MFA meeting was held where the moderate wing, led by Major Melo Antunes, managed to ensure that Otelo was not arrested and that the Communist Party remained a legal party at the service of democracy. The 25th of November, a political dispute, but essentially between military personnel, was immediately announced as a “heroic” restoration of the democratic state. Third important note: never in more than 50 years of democracy have right-wing political forces remembered to officially celebrate November 25, 1975. Last week, we found that the 25th of November was officially celebrated with pomp and circumstance and, obviously, with the support of right-wing and extreme-right political forces, with the disagreement of the Socialist Party and other left-wing political parties and, aggravatingly, the date was celebrated in the Assembly of the Republic with the presence of President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa. The truth is that we witnessed the positions of individuals defending fascist and neo-Nazi policies, stating that the celebrations of November 25th “were much more important than those of April 25th”. We no longer have any doubts that the political system in Portugal is changing. A dangerous change. A change in which racists, xenophobes and neo-Nazis advance proposals in Parliament that garner the support of the elected Montenegro Government, which announces itself as democratic. No, my friends. We must realize that the political change we are witnessing could end in a dictatorship disguised as democracy, where prisons and a lack of press freedom will be a reality.

item.title: Annual report
item.description: Before we analyze the Government Action Lines Report for the year 2026, let me share a story with you. On a mountain, there were two monasteries. The monks from Monastery A did not get along very well with each other, while the monks from Monastery B were always cordial with each other. The abbot of Monastery A went to ask the abbot of Monastery B, “why did his monks maintain such friendly relations”. The abbot of Monastery B replied, “We often make mistakes.” While the abbot of Monastery A was trying to understand the answer, a monk from Monastery B entered the corridor, slipped and fell to the floor. Another monk who was washing the floor immediately ran to apologize for what happened, saying that the floor was wet because of him, while another monk who was standing at the door also came to apologize for not having warned the one who had fallen that the floor was wet. After they helped him to his feet, the first monk said, "Thank you, but it was my fault. I was walking too fast and I wasn't careful." The abbot of Monastery A saw what had just happened and said to the abbot of Monastery B, “Thank you, I think I have the answer to my question.” For the members of a society to live in harmony, in addition to being aware of the mistakes of others, they must first be aware of their own mistakes. It's easy to pass the blame onto others and it's difficult to take responsibility for ourselves. Macau is a city with more than 600,000 inhabitants and has substantial revenues from taxation on gambling and tourist activity, so it is not that difficult for the Government to look after all its citizens. In the Government Action Lines Report for the year 2026, it is mentioned that many measures will be implemented to promote the well-being of the population and tax benefits that can meet the needs of the majority of people. Although the content of the Report is full of visionary ideas, and the present budget is quite good, does this mean that there are no aspects that cannot be reviewed and improved? For example, the Macao SAR Government has yet to publish the results of monitoring suicides for the second quarter of 2025. According to media estimates, based on information from the Security Forces and Services, at least 40 suicides occurred between April and October 2025, and the newspaper Hoje Macau published a report on this subject. On the day of the election of deputies to the 8th Legislature of the Legislative Assembly, last September, the Chief Executive, Sam Hou Fai, was questioned by Hong Kong journalists about non-resident workers and suicides in Macau. Sam Hou Fai did not respond, limiting himself to stating that the questions were not related to the elections and that he would respond on another occasion. Health Services encourages people who feel hopeless and are experiencing emotional problems to call the Caritas Life Support Line (2852 5222) for advice. For more information about psychological well-being, you can visit the Health Services mental health information webpage. While the helpline and information provided through the mental health webpage are undoubtedly helpful, how can you help those who do not call or visit the webpage? Because suicide numbers for the period indicated above were not published, it does not mean that they did not occur. For Macau to truly be a “happy city”, cases of “discovery of dead bodies” should not be so frequent. When answering journalists' questions, the Chief Executive mentioned the success of the election for the 8th Legislative Assembly and the first case in Macau involving the State Security Defense Law. Following the guiding principle “Macau governed by patriots”, the election of deputies for the 8th Legislative Assembly passed smoothly. However, it is regrettable that Lam Yu Tou, who was considered loyal to the Macao SAR in 2021, was disqualified and prevented from running for election to the Legislative Assembly in 2025. On the other hand, the record of 5,987 blank votes and 7,053 invalid votes in these direct elections is quite worrying. As for the trial of the first case in Macau involving the State Security Defense Law, I believe it will probably attract a lot of public attention in 2026. There should not be too much criticism directed at the Chief Executive and his team, as improving the efficiency of governance and promoting the diversification of the economy is not an easy task and requires the cooperation of all members of society. It is not difficult to list our ten strengths, but listing our ten weaknesses is something that not everyone can do. The Government Action Lines Report for the year 2026 is well written, but what citizens want above all is that its practical result will be equally excellent.

item.title: Germany's Strategic Awakening (II)
item.description: “The claim that a state’s security interest necessarily coincides with that of its citizens appears downright absurd.” Ole Nymoen If the draconian dictates of the Morgenthau Plan proposed by the United States in 1944 to demilitarize and deindustrialize Germany after World War II, transforming it into an agrarian country and incapable of starting new conflicts remained a dead letter, it was only because, in those same months, awareness of a fundamental conflict in Europe with the Soviet Union began to mature in the United States. As the weeks went by, the priority stopped being the neutralization of Germany and became preventing Moscow from absorbing it into its sphere of influence. In the interpretation of several American officials at the time, before reaching the Atlantic, the Red Army would have to seize the industrial capabilities of the Rhineland and the Ruhr region, the historic heart of German industry, with emphasis on the coal, steel, chemical, energy and logistics sectors. Hence the need to rebuild a West German state and direct its economic, human and technological potential against Soviet expansionism. Summarized in a 1949 CIA document, the United States' objective became “the permanent control of German power”. Eighty years later, the contours have changed, not the substance. Today, for Washington, the challenge of the century is called China, and the costs of defending the Old Continent must fall on the Europeans. France and the United Kingdom's financial room for maneuver is limited, also due to their expensive nuclear arsenals. And, from the point of view of the Poles, Balts and Scandinavians, Russia is an existential threat, to be contained and eroded by all means. Everything points in a single direction, which is German rearmament. According to this logic, it will be up to Germany to ensure the critical mass of economic resources and conventional forces that the remaining Western partners cannot or do not want to mobilize. Naturally, an essential assumption of this bet is that Berlin does not act on its own, building a sphere of influence or pursuing strictly national interests. Only then can it be understood that the Federal Republic, whose legal system theoretically prohibits even the sending of weapons to areas of armed conflict, is currently debating whether to place troops on the ground in Ukraine. In recent years, the Germans have broken several long-standing taboos, such as the debt brake, but this would be, for obvious reasons, the most clamorous. Thus, in August, at the end of the Washington summit, Merz stressed that Germany has a “fundamental interest” in cooperating to offer guarantees to Kiev, with the image of the chancellor in the role of a sinister Uncle Sam, accompanied by the caption that “Merz wants to send you to Ukraine? Not us!” To this day, this is not only an unpopular perspective according to a recent poll, as 51 percent of Germans are against it and only 36 percent are in favor, but it is also technically impractical. Despite the significant increase in military expenditure, the number of personnel in the German Armed Forces continues to decline and age. The objective of 203,000 units by 2031 seems out of reach, a goal that the strategic community of Berlin-Mitte, the most central and historic district of Berlin, considered the political, cultural and tourist heart of the German capital, considers totally insufficient to meet current German security needs. In the last three years, the approximately 180 thousand employees have decreased slightly. It is difficult to imagine that the military service reform recently approved by the federal government could represent the solution, as recruitment, for now, will continue to be voluntary. We are not, therefore, faced with a linear process. But it is worth remembering that, no matter how much legions of experts strive every day to present German rearmament as the panacea for all the ills of the West, it continues to be a high-risk bet. Above all because the European strategic context is radically different from the one that, in the post-war period, led Washington to allow itself to be convinced by London and Paris not to abandon Europe. At the time, it was French leaders, particularly figures like Robert Schuman and Jean Monnet, who firmly argued that any withdrawal of American troops would have “disastrous consequences” for the national security of the victors. And in the United States there was full awareness that the rapprochement between France and Germany was a fundamental condition for giving solidity to the Western bloc. As Secretary of State Dean Acheson, who played a central role in formulating American foreign policy during the early years of the Cold War, stated in 1949, “Only France can take the decisive lead in the integration of Germany in Western Europe… if it is to avoid Russian or German or perhaps Russian-German domination in Europe.” Having all due consideration for the pro-European rhetoric, without the security guarantees of the United States there would not have been any Franco-German axis, the true engine of European integration. The proof is there for all to see and is it a coincidence that the partial American disengagement with the continent coincides today with a crisis in relations between Germany and France? Washington seems increasingly distant. Old wounds resurface, never fully healed. In particular, the origin of tensions between the two banks of the Rhine lies in an opposing perception of German rearmament. Paris fears that the Federal Republic could transform into an assertive power unrelated to any control. Berlin, for its part, suspects that the French intend to use German funds to further their expensive ambitions. This is a structural fracture, impossible to completely bridge, regardless of the good will of Merz and Macron. (Continues)

item.title: Book | “Receita di Casa” by Antonieta Manhão awarded in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Macanese chef Antonieta Manhão, better known as “Chef Neta”, has just seen her work honored with two awards in Saudi Arabia. More specifically, the book “Receita di Casa” won two awards in the international competition “Gourmand Awards Food Culture”, in the Gourmet categories and in the group of trilingual publications, Portuguese, Chinese and English, which were awarded in Riyadh. This is a book edited by Dorris Lei, from Co-Write Limited, translated by Adelaide Ferreira. Of note is the more than 1,200 works sent to this competition, with six being selected for the final of the group of recipe publications, with the aim of distinguishing “The Best Cookbooks in The World”. At the awards ceremony, 96 countries were represented. “Receita di Casa” was launched in January this year and features 19 recipes for typical Macanese dishes, namely the famous Minchi, Capela or Sopa Lacassá, among many others. “Neta” Manhão is also a professor of Macanese cuisine at the Macau Tourism University.

item.title: “Spiritual Narrative” exhibition this Thursday at Casas da Taipa
item.description: This Thursday, the exhibition “Spiritual Narrative – Annual Arts Exhibition between China and Portuguese-Speaking Countries” will be presented to the public, starting at 6:30 p.m., at the Casas da Taipa Exhibition Gallery, as part of the program of the 7th Meeting in Macau – Festival of Arts and Culture between China and Portuguese-Speaking Countries. This is an initiative organized by the Cultural Institute (IC) and brings together the work of eight artists from China and Portuguese-speaking countries, namely Cao Yu and Tong Wenmin, from Mainland China; Wong Hio Chit and Cosmo Wong from Macau, China; Carla Cabanas, from Portugal; Délio Jasse, from Angola; Eugénia Mussa, from Mozambique; and Juliana Matsumura, from Brazil. The exhibition presents works in different media, covering painting, sculpture, video and installation, revealing a mosaic of the cultural contexts of China and Portuguese-speaking Countries, “expressed through a rich artistic vocabulary”, highlights the IC, in a note. Curatorial notes To organize this exhibition and its content, the curators based themselves on “the experience of two legendary travelers from the 16th century, one from the West and the other from the East: the Portuguese Fernão Mendes Pinto and the Chinese Xu Xiake”, both of whom, according to the IC, “measured the world with their own steps, transforming their observations and travel experiences into philosophical reflections on life”. The exhibition “uses artistic creation in place of physical travel, offering visitors a visual feast through 28 pieces/sets of works in various media”. The possible visitor experience is described, which could be similar to “following in the footsteps of a traveler, starting an artistic tour of self-reflection and exploration of the world”. This exhibition can be visited until March 1st of next year, between 10am and 7pm, free of charge. During this month, guided tours will be available in Cantonese and Mandarin, respectively at 3pm and 4pm, every Saturday, Sunday and public holiday, as well as on the 23rd and 26th.

item.title: Consulate | “Camões Cinco Zero Zero”, by Vítor Marreiros, travels from Lisbon to Macau
item.description: After a period on display at the Passevite gallery, in Lisbon, the exhibition “Camões Cinco Zero Zero” now arrives at Macao SAR. It is a set of works by designer and artist Vítor Marreiros, which presents visions and interpretations of the great poet of the Portuguese language. To see until the 27th, at the Consulate of Portugal It is entitled “Camões Cinco Zero Zero” and was held in Lisbon in the summer as the first exhibition by Vítor Marreiros presented, individually, in Portugal. At the Passevite gallery, the work of this Macanese designer and artist who regularly makes posters commemorating the 10th of June for the Casa de Portugal in Macau was revealed to the Portuguese public. Thus, on the walls of this independent gallery, images of Luís de Camões were gathered, taken from posters, and adorned with new guises and interpretations. The exhibition now travels to Macau, almost in a return to its origins, being exhibited thanks to the initiative of the Consulate-General of Portugal in Macau and Hong Kong and the Instituto Português do Oriente, until the 27th of December. The inauguration takes place tomorrow, starting at 6:30 pm, and the exhibition can be visited daily between 3:30 pm and 6:30 pm, specifically in the Gallery of the Official Residence of the Consul General, on Rua do Comendador Kou Hó Neng. According to a note from the Consulate, “the exhibition marks the 500th anniversary of the birth of Luís de Camões, based on an original idea by designer Henrique Silva (Bibito), proposing a contemporary and symbolic reading of the poet's figure through the posters that Victor Marreiros has created over more than three decades to celebrate the 10th of June in Macau”. Camões appears here “removed from its usual context” and “reinterpreted with graphic freedom, humor and critical spirit, in a series that is, simultaneously, memory and creation”. This “symbolically closes the cycle of a project that unites the two margins of Portuguese heritage and celebrates the dialogue between art, history and identity”. During the exhibition period, a special silkscreen edition numbered and signed by the artist will be available, as well as the official exhibition catalogue. Contemporary themes In Lisbon, HM spoke with Vítor Hugo Marreiros, who spoke about his long connection with Camões, through drawing and imagination, and the work he has been doing for several years with the posters that celebrate such an important date for Portugal. “It all came from the challenge proposed by a colleague of mine, Henrique Silva, better known as Bibito”, he told HM. “The paintings here are not only taken from the 10th of June posters, but also from other works, because throughout my professional life I have had countless opportunities to portray Portuguese themes and icons such as Fernando Pessoa, Amália, even the sardine”, he said. There are 34 years of posters and figures that portray Portugal and the themes of this community. Around Vítor Marreiros’ images there is not only literature, but also more contemporary issues. "In recent years I have tried to portray the concerns of the Portuguese community [of Macau], as well as events in Portugal, the crisis, Covid-19 or the war in Ukraine. Camões speaks for itself, in different years and always accompanied by the events of the year. Sometimes I have Camões speak for me. My partner always tells me that, and I have Camões say what I want."

item.title: Government highlights calendar with nighttime activities this month
item.description: The Directorate of Tourism Services (DST) highlights that this month will be marked by the holding of several night programs, many of them already in the Christmas spirit, and integrated into the subsidies program for associations with a view to diversifying tourist activity. One of these events kicked off yesterday and runs until this Sunday, the 7th, entitled “The Cities of Gastronomy (China) in Macao 2025”, with “the participation of renowned chefs and leaders of the culinary sector from Chengdu, Shunde, Yangzhou, Huai’an, Chaozhou and Macau, to promote cultural exchange between the six Creative Cities of Gastronomy”. This is an event that includes round tables, specialty tasting sessions, a forum on the development of Chinese gastronomy, a culinary evening and an exchange of famous Chinese chefs, highlights a note from DST. Between Saturday and March 5th next year, the event “Luminescent Night at Travessa do Armazém Velho 2025” will take place, with the “transformation of streets and alleys into a theater of immersive light”. In this activity, “interactive equipment, online games and in-person workshops, among other experiences, are used to promote the flow of people and stimulate night-time consumption in this area”. Everything so that the “Travessa do Armazém Velho area shows its unique charm at night”. Other cultures Also noteworthy is the usual holding of the “Thailand Cultural Festival 2025”, this weekend, the 6th and 7th, on Rua de Abreu Nunes. 20 Thai food stands will be installed at the site, and there will also be shows such as rice delivery and blessing and good fortune activities, Thai massage, traditional ethnic dance, Thai songs and dances, among others. The “Northern Winter Market” is scheduled for the 20th to 28th of December, at Praça Flor de Lótus in Bairro da Ilha Verde, featuring this event with market stalls and themed games, in order to “increase the tourist attractiveness of the northern area. DST says it has approved 54 activities within the scope of the support plan for this year, and, from January to October, 39 of these projects were completed, attracting more than 650 thousand participants. item.title: Flu | Outbreaks in schools affect 87 students
item.description: The Health Services announced yesterday that 10 collective cases of influenza were detected in schools in Macau, affecting 87 students, 40 of whom tested positive in a rapid test for type A influenza. The educational establishment with the highest number of incidents was the Fong Chong da Taipa School, on Rua de Chaves, where 20 students were infected in three different classes. Both at the Flora Official School, in Travessa do Túnel, and at the Vocational and Technical Secondary School of the General Workers' Association, on Rua de Lei Pou Chon, each registered 10 students with the flu. The remaining schools where these cases were found were the School of the General Association of Women of Macau, the Colégio Diocesano de São José (V, Chinese Section), the Colégio Sagrado Coração Canossiano (English Section), the D. José da Costa Nunes Kindergarten (Taipa), the Choi Nong Chi Tai School, the Choi Nong Chi Tai School, the Santa Rosa de Lima College (Chinese Section) and the Talent School Attached to the Hou Secondary School. Kong. Despite indicating that some patients received medical treatment, the Health Services emphasized that the “patients' clinical conditions are considered mild and no serious cases or other complications were recorded”.

item.title: HIV | Macau hosts joint conference on virus and disease
item.description: An ancient global scourge is today a mere chronic disease, treatable with medication. However, the HIV virus is still present and it is with this problem in mind that Macau hosts this weekend, at the Grand Lisboa Palace, the 8th Forum on AIDS in Beijing, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan, organized by a local association The Macao AIDS Care Association is promoting, this Saturday and Sunday, the 8th Beijing, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan AIDS Forum, taking place at Lisboeta Macau, in Cotai. This is an event that aims to draw attention to a pathology that evolved into a chronic disease due to the scourge of deaths it caused in the 1980s, but which continues to be present and alert authorities around the world. According to a statement sent by the association, the aim is to “bring together renowned experts to discuss critical issues of HIV prevention, treatment and social support”. The event aims to cover topics such as “the public health strategy”, namely “the latest developments in policies and technologies related to HIV, including the application of artificial intelligence”, or even “social issues”, such as “important discussions on eliminating stigma and supporting elderly populations living with HIV”. Other topics on the agenda relate to the “local impact”, namely “Macau’s role as host and collaborator in this important inter-regional dialogue”. Fight stigma The conference's theme is “Together wih Love, Not Alone in the Fight” and has the support of entities such as The Home of Red Ribbon, Hong Kong Aids Foundation and Macau Association for Gender Diverse Community, which, as the name suggests, draws attention to gender equality. The description of the event states that “medical advances have not been accompanied by a proportionate level of understanding and social acceptance”, with “stigma, discrimination and social isolation [which are] deeply rooted” remaining” and which “continue to cause a great psychological impact and lead to systemic marginalization, preventing many people from accessing equitable care and living with dignity”. There is, therefore, a “critical gap between medical progress and the delay in social support”, which this forum aims to provide answers to. “We focus on two objectives, ‘Eliminating Stigma’ and ‘Building Robust Support Systems’, translating scientific knowledge into tangible and inclusive social practices”, it is described. One of the speakers comes from Italy, namely from the University of Modena and Reggio Emilia. Giovanni Guaraldi will speak, on the first day, about “Person-centered approach to HIV care: Why does it matter and how to make it happen?”. growing The most recent HIV data in Macau, released in November by the Health Services, speaks of a growing trend: between January and September this year, 28 new cases of HIV infection were registered, 14 of which were among residents and 14 among non-residents. In comparison, between January and September last year, nine cases had been confirmed among residents, which means that throughout this year there has been a 55.6 percent increase in new cases. In last year's statement, there was no reference to infected non-residents. “Among the new cases confirmed in Macau residents, all are male, with 50 percent aged between 18 and 39 years old and 50 percent aged 40 or over”, the authorities reported. Of these cases, 13 of the infections were contracted through homosexual or bisexual intercourse, while one of the cases indicated that it resulted from heterosexual sexual intercourse. “All new cases were referred to the Centro Hospitalar Conde de São Januário for monitoring and, currently, the treatment and control rate for Macau residents exceeds 90 percent”, it was added.

item.title: Satellite Casinos | Kam Pek closed its doors
item.description: The Kam Pek Paradise casino, linked to the concessionaire SJM Resorts, closed its doors at 11:31 pm on Monday. In a statement, the Gaming Inspection and Coordination Directorate (DICJ) considered that the closure took place “in accordance with the established procedures”. “After the closure of the Casino Kam Pek Paradise, at 11:59 pm on December 1st, the DICJ immediately suspended the operation of the tables and gaming machines, having ensured active coordination with various services, to monitor the removal of the respective premises, among other work”, was communicated by the authorities. “During the closure of the aforementioned casino, the Directorate of Labor Affairs Services sent staff to the site to provide clarifications to the workers in question, and they were provided with information on an open line for further consultation”, it was added. The number of workers affected by layoffs was not communicated by the DICJ, which also did not make reference to the number of workers who will be transferred to SJM Resorts. In July this year, when it was confirmed that the Kam Pek Paradise casino was going to close, the news caused surprise among analysts. A statement from CLSA that month indicated that the closure was unexpected, given that the casino was run at a profit.

item.title: Metro | Daily average of 32,600 passengers in November
item.description: In November, the Light Rail transported around 32,600 passengers per day, a new record since trips began to be paid. The statistics were made available on the company portal that operates this means of transport. Calculated per month, the Light Rail transported 978 thousand passengers. This is a record that is close to the numbers from December 2019, when the means of transport was inaugurated. That year, in December, the daily average of passengers was 33 thousand per day, for a total of around 693 thousand passengers, given that the inauguration took place on December 10th. However, during that period passengers did not have to pay for tickets, a measure that continued until January 2020.

item.title: Fortune | Closure affects 553 workers
item.description: The Gaming Inspection and Coordination Directorate (DICJ) confirmed that Casino Fortuna will close its doors next Tuesday, a measure that will affect the employment of 553 workers. The number of other workers linked to the company responsible for space exploration was not revealed. “Regarding the 553 workers at Casino Fortuna, DICJ will continue to maintain close communication with DSAL, in order to ensure compliance with the commitments made by SJM, with regard to the relocation of all respective workers, as well as guarantees regarding their remuneration, benefits and working conditions, providing them with opportunities to change jobs, with a view to continuing their employment”, it was communicated.

item.title: Housing | Sales and prices with annual drops in November
item.description: In the first half of November, fewer houses were sold and at cheaper prices, compared to the same period in 2024. Transactions fell 18.6 percent, while prices fell 9.1 percent. The usable area of ​​properties sold also decreased by more than 10 percent annually. The residential property market continued to fall in the first half of November. According to data released yesterday by the Financial Services Directorate, in the first half of November, 118 housing units were sold in the territory, 27 fewer compared to the same period last year, or a reduction of 18.6 percent. Statistical data based on stamp duty for the transfer of goods also reveals that the average price per square meter followed a downward trend, with a drop of 9.1 percent, to 66,315 patacas. Even the usable area of ​​sold homes decreased by 10.1 percent to 71 square meters In the period under review, the biggest drops in sales and prices occurred in Taipa, with a total of 21 houses sold, 15 fewer compared to the first half of November 2024, representing a drop of 41.7 percent. Residential property prices in Taipa also fell by 10.2 percent, reaching an average of MOP64,510 per square meter. On the peninsula, where 90 of the total 118 units were sold, transactions recorded a decrease of 11.8 percent. The price also decreased from 72,613 patacas per square meter to 66,476 patacas per square meter, that is, 8.4 percent less. In the most expensive market (Coloane) seven properties were sold in the first half of November, the same number in annual terms. However, the price per square meter fell 10 percent to 75,946 patacas. Closer in time In monthly terms, property values ​​follow the same trend, despite the greater number of sales driven by the peninsula market. In total, house sales increased in the first half of November, compared to the same period in October, by 3.5 percent, going from 114 transactions to 118, with the market “heating up” slightly on the peninsula with an increase of 9.7 percent. This is not surprising, given that the peninsula was the area of ​​Macau where prices fell the most in monthly terms: 13.4 percent. In Taipa, sales were maintained (11) and prices rose 5.5 percent, but in Coloane the monthly drop in sales was more severe (-36.4 percent), despite the drop in square meter prices of 11.3 percent. Taking the entire territory of Macau into account, prices suffered a negative monthly variation of 9.9 percent, falling from 73,632 patacas to 66,315 patacas per square meter.

item.title: Accident | Drunk man drove in the opposite direction
item.description: In the early hours of Saturday, November 29th, an accident occurred with a drunk resident who drove in the opposite direction. According to the newspaper Ou Mun, the accident, which occurred around 1:55 am, culminated in a collision with another car that was parked in a space with a parking meter. The drunk man ended up admitting to the authorities that he had consumed excessive amounts of alcohol, having recorded 1.73 grams per liter of blood. The resident, aged around 30, declared that he was a bar employee, having had dinner at a restaurant on Saturday night at around 10pm, in the Avenida Horta e Costa area, where after consuming alcohol, he drove the car around 1:45am. At the intersection between Avenida do Almirante Lacerda and Avenida de Horta e Costa, the man drove in the opposite direction, and after realizing the infraction he reversed to return to the correct lane. Near Estrada do Campo, he collided with a car that was parked there. The Public Security Police used images from video surveillance cameras to understand what had happened, confirming the statement. The owner of the affected vehicle was contacted and the damage is still being investigated. The case was, however, referred to the Public Prosecutor's Office for further investigation, with the driver being charged with the crime of driving under the influence of alcohol, aggravated by driving in the opposite direction and causing a traffic accident.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary.
