It is also worth noting how they reinvented themselves and intensified to collect and distribute food items and mask/alcohol gel kits to the most expropriated people. Gypsies and non-gypsies. In the anti-racist fight, new movements emerged and their actions intensified through social media. People who had never organized or become active before began their first steps in activism, joining this path of gypsy and anti-racist organization and popular action. People forget, or don't want to appreciate, but gypsy action has helped to determine results in the political dispute. Gypsy citizens mobilized in large numbers and determined electoral results in the 2017 local councils, both in Alentejo and in the Lisbon Metropolitan Area, even causing electoral earthquakes. And even in the Presidential elections, second place was decided by an amount equivalent to the estimated number of gypsy voters. Apart from the non-gypsy votes that were mobilized by the action of gypsy voters. Gypsy people are even co-building power in opinion spaces, in local media, on social networks and in party and institutional political disputes. And most importantly, in popular action and in alliances with other social movements. We never stopped fighting by all means and we continued to resist. On the other hand, there is more and more hate speech, from the far right in particular. What do you have to say about that? To begin with, these speeches are historical and European. They are neither current nor “extreme right-wing”. These speeches have been adopted and delivered for a long time, even in 'democracy and freedom', by various representatives of the center-right, conservatives, center-left, liberals, liberal left, even representatives of the PCP. Anti-gypsy rhetoric has always worked in Portugal, as it is the most white-natured rhetoric. That is, it allows the creation and recognition of “white” as the superior of all. And thus please the white electorate who, when they feel good, compensate with their vote. Even if the policies implemented by your elected officials harm you even more. Finally, I would like you to talk a little about your personal experience and how you became an activist? I studied, fought for my studies, made alliances, graduated, and entered the “formal precarious” job market. I started my militant action and here I am today. We can transform this society into a better one. This certainty, combined with the fact that the current one has so much suffering, makes anyone want to have a transformative attitude. I wanted to be an ‘inventor’ (physical engineer) and an anti-racist activist. And through study (not necessarily schooling) and organization with other people, in turn, with other studies, training and visions, I learned how the world works and how it can be changed. But before transforming, we need to survive. This gives rise to two types of actions: transformative and survival. The fight against hate speech appears as survival, but its defeat will be a transformative victory. There is a lot that – as people who want a better world – we have to do, namely work to criminalize hate speech; condemn and ban organizations with racist speeches and practices; denounce the racist institutional structure and logic that organizes Power and manages community resources. And in this sense, there have been various types of actions, from petitions to demonstrations. And we need more. In addition to being a member of the SOS RACISMO movement, I participate in the Podcast “Viemos Para Ficar”, with Mamadou Ba and Joseph da Silva. And if everything goes well, we will soon start a new project. With friendly people, we also have the “Cigana Initiative” project, dedicated to reflecting and promoting transformative movements. Essentially focused on educating against anti-gypsyism, denouncing historical and ongoing genocide and working towards a new societal project. Also with new projects in the pipeline. And finally, there are always voluntary actions, without an organization, where I try to share what I discovered about Anti-Gypsyism and Romani history in schools and with interested people. In addition, there is still the struggle for housing, because evictions did not stop during the pandemic. Due to housing and employment precariousness, racialized individuals, especially Roma nationals, are the most vulnerable to Covid-19. It is essential to have actions in this area; Of all the struggles, this is the most structural, as it goes against one of the main enemies of a healthy society: the real estate speculation of this capitalist system, which puts profit and goods above people and their humanization.

item.title: Roadsport | Badaraco took the podium on his birthday, but ended up penalized
item.description: On his birthday, Badaraco recovered from 17th to reach second place on the podium. Hours after the party, the bad news arrived, with a penalty relegating him to 15th. Rui Valente was placed off the track, after recovering several positions On his birthday, Jerónimo Badaraco climbed to second place on the podium of the Roadsport Challenge race, after starting from 17th. However, the worst came later, when the top three, all local drivers, were penalized and relegated in the general classification, for overtaking other cars that had lost their way before the starting line, after the safety car had left. The Macanese driver had a setback when he was relegated to 15th, after an almost perfect race: “It was very unfair and I think the stewards don't know what they are doing”, said Jerónimo. "I think the decision was not transparent. After the safety car came out, several drivers hit the barriers... of course we thought they weren't going to continue in the race after those crashes and we had to overtake them", he explained. “And even if we had stopped or slowed down in the face of these drivers' missteps, we would have created a much more dangerous situation for everyone, because the cars behind us would have been surprised by our braking, meaning there would have been more accidents”, he explained. Even so, the Macanese assured HM that the penalty would not ruin his day: “I will continue to enjoy the day, I went up to the podium, drank the champagne, took the photos… More cup, less cup, I will continue to celebrate”, he guaranteed with a laugh. Hours earlier, Badaraco had already explained that reaching the podium in Guia “is a different feeling” that justifies “80 percent” his choice to drive 26 years ago. The driver was also satisfied with the race, considering that no one can take away the merit of what he achieved on the track, as he rose from 17th to 2nd: "Before the race I thought a lot about how I was going to approach the start, to recover positions, and I was confident of a good result. The most important thing was not to have given up, after qualifying, and not to have stopped believing that it was possible to reach the podium", explained the Macanese driver. “I know that the Guia Circuit always has a lot of changes throughout the race, there are a lot of safety cars and yellow flags, and I knew I had the experience, and also the calm, to be able to take advantage of the opportunities”, he highlighted. “They ruined my race” In turn, Rui Valente gave up and appeared disappointed, due to what he considered to be an excess on the part of the driver who tried to overtake him on the inside, on the curve leading to the São Francisco road. "I don't know what was going through the driver's head who tried to overtake me. I can't understand how he saw a space that simply didn't exist!", said Valente. "I was put out of the race. When I tried to make the turn, he touched me and that was it, my rear end was damaged and I had to go back to the pits to retire", he reported. When the crash occurred that ended the race, Valente was circulating in the top 10, even after a less successful start, following the exit of the first Safety Car. Despite this aspect, the Macanese came to believe that it was possible to achieve a result in the top five: “I had a good pace, I was confident and I think I would achieve a result in the top five... It's the races...”, he lamented. The Macanese also took stock of a “complicated” weekend in which he was also involved in another accident during the free practice session. "To be honest, it wasn't one of the weekends I had the most fun in Macau. I had that first touch, which conditioned my qualifying. In the race I actually did well, gaining positions, but they put me off the track...", he highlighted. At 64 years old, Rui Valente now admits that he may be left out of the next edition of the Grand Prix: “With such a difficult qualifying model for Macau and then with races with so many accidents, I will consider what to do in the future”, he confessed. “I don't want to sit still, I want to stay active and involved in different activities, so if I find an activity that occupies me and makes me feel good, maybe I'll stay out of racing next year”, he said. item.title: Grand Prix Shorts
item.description: Spectators | More than 110 thousand passed through the stands Over the four days of the Macau Grand Prix, more than 110 thousand people passed through the stands of the Guia Circuit, an increase compared to last year, which was marked by the passage of a typhoon. According to official figures, the good weather helped and on Thursday there were more than 15 thousand spectators, on Friday around 28 thousand and on Saturday 35 thousand. Yesterday, on the day of the main races, the number of spectators was over 32 thousand. Tobacco | Harmony Racing fined Driver Ye Yifei's Harmony Racing team was fined 500 euros after one of its members was caught smoking in the garage. According to the stewards' sanction, the team member was smoking when he was approached by those responsible. When he was caught, he immediately put out his cigarette, inside a glass, containing five other butts. Great Bay | Lu Wenlong has become superior Lu Wenlong (Lotus Emira) was the winner of the GT Cup-Greater Bay Race, finishing ahead of Han Lichao (Toyota GR Supra GT4 Evo2) and Liu Kai Shun (Lotus Emira). The experienced Leong Ian Veng (BMW M4 GT4) was the best driver in Macau, finishing in fourth place, very close to the podium. In what he admitted was a farewell to Guia, Darryl O’Young (Mercedes AMG GT4 EVO), who competed in the GT Cup for several years, did nothing more than withdraw. The Hong Kong driver crashed the Mercedes when he went head-on at the entrance to the San Francisco climb. Organization | Satisfactory event The coordinator of the Organizing Committee considered that the event ran satisfactorily and that it contributed, together with the National Games, to creating a festive atmosphere in Macau. Lei Si Leng highlighted the value of the seven races in the program for the Grand Prix, which he said was wonderful. When asked about a possible return of Formula 3, the official stated that the organization will continue to cooperate with the FIA ​​to choose the races that best suit Macau. At the same time, he left the guarantee that the plan involves continuing to receive drivers of training age and that they are expected to establish themselves as the future of motorsport.

item.title: GP | FIA will continue to invest in Formula Regional in Macau
item.description: The fact that the FIA ​​switched from Formula 3 to Formula Regional (FR) continues to be a recurring theme when the topic is the Macau Grand Prix. Although the show's premier race did not disappoint in this year's edition, somewhat erasing the bad image left last year, there is still a widespread feeling that the international federation deprived the Grand Prix of its favorite race. At the end of the 72nd edition, the Coordinator of the Organizing Committee of the Macau Grand Prix, Lei Si Leng, when questioned again by the local press about a possible return of Formula 3, stated that the organization will continue to cooperate with the FIA ​​to choose the races that best suit Macau. At the same time, the director of the Macau Sports Institute left the guarantee that the plan involves continuing to receive drivers of training age and who assert themselves as the future of motorsport. “We have been communicating closely with the FIA ​​to find out which races can be held in Macau and the FIA ​​has selected the best drivers to come and compete here”, he said, adding that he hopes “that the best drivers can come to Macau and that we continue to collaborate with the FIA ​​to organize the most suitable races for Macau”. On the FIA ​​side, there is the conviction that FR is the discipline that best adapts to the characteristics of the Guia Circuit, a layout that remains practically unchanged after seven decades of existence. The discontent that still exists is considered natural. “Motor sport is traditional, and I don't remember any change that was well received at the beginning, even good changes” admitted Emanuele Pirro, the current president of the FIA ​​Single Seater Commission, in conversation with journalists in Macau. The former Italian driver, a connoisseur of the Guia Circuit and winner of the Guia Race with BMW, took advantage of his time in the Macao SAR to remember that “if we look at the history of Macau, it started with Formula 2, or Formula Pacific, and then moved on to Formula 3. In 1984, a journalist could have asked: 'why don't we race in Formula 2 anymore?' I think it's inevitable. Everything has a price. For us to have the privilege of having a circuit that has remained unchanged since Throughout its history, the price to pay is to use cars that continue to be reasonably safe. And I think Formula Regional offers a good balance in terms of speed.” In a rare interview with the specialized magazine INSIDE, the former coordinator of the Grand Prix, José Manuel Costa Antunes, warned against letting the level of the race drop. "Today, with the transition to Formula Regional and Formula 4, which is not a problem, they are just different cars, we see more inexperienced drivers", said the man who was at the helm of the event for the longest time, touching on a sensitive topic: "Some people can simply buy a seat. That is worrying. As fans, we want real races, not red flags. We owe it to the history of the Grand Prix to recover that selection process, to ensure that only the best compete here." Numbers support the decision Looking at the time sheets, it can be concluded that the records for the main FR race were around 2m16s, around ten seconds slower than the times recorded in the last year of the FIA F3 single-seaters, in 2023. In historical terms, these times place the FR cars on a level similar to that of the Formula 3 cars of the late 1990s. However, from a safety point of view, the speeds reached in the “Sprint” for Curva Lisboa continues to be the main concern since Sophia Flörsch’s accident in 2018. With the suction cone, speeds above 290 km/h were common in 2023 with the Dallara F3, but the change to FR cars reduced these values to around 260 km/h. In 2026, the new Formula Regional car, the Tatuus T-326, is expected to arrive in Macau, which is equipped with a three-cylinder, 1.6-liter Toyota ATM163T engine, prepared by Autotecnica Motori, which is more powerful and efficient. The chassis was designed according to the latest FIA specifications, in order to provide improvements in terms of performance, safety and aerodynamics, facilitating overtaking and promoting more lively racing. However, although lap times are expected to drop again, top speeds will probably not be dramatically higher. It should be noted that the change to FR was not motivated solely by security concerns. When the FIA ​​granted Formula One Management (FOM) the commercial and promotional rights for Formula 3, the territory's race became a non-championship race of an international competition, limited to the participation of the same teams that competed in the championship. This change was received unfavorably by the promoter himself, as he never played a truly intervening role within the Grand Prix. Furthermore, holding the race in Macau, in November, involved particularly demanding logistics, with a negative impact on the planning and execution of pre-season tests.

item.title: Motorsport | GP will continue on the TCR World Tour in 2026
item.description: The Macau Grand Prix will once again form part of the Kumho FIA TCR World Tour calendar next season and, once again, as the season-ending event of a competition that will increase its presence in Asia in 2026 Marcelo Lotti, president of the WSC Group, confirmed to the press, during the weekend of the 72nd Macau Grand Prix, that next year's calendar should include a race in South Korea – home country of the tire brand and championship sponsor, Kumho, as well as Hyundai, the brand with the most cars on the starting grids of the world competition -, a second race in the People's Republic of China and the traditional end-of-season round at the Guia Circuit. To increase the presence on the Asian continent, without affecting the teams' budgets, Australia will be left out of the calendar. The championship promoter will also not move forward with the possibility of organizing a second race on the American continent, with a visit to Mexico being a certainty. Already on the “old continent”, the Kumho FIA TCR World Tour will maintain its three events, with the Portuguese city circuit of Vila Real hosting one of these events in July. For Marcello Lotti, “the Macau Grand Prix is ​​our equivalent to Monaco”, and for the Italian businessman, “all championships need an event like this”. Despite the smaller number of entrants that this year's event gathered in the territory, “leaving Macau is obviously out of the question”. The 2026 Kumho FIA TCR World Tour season calendar is expected to be revealed to the public on December 13, when the FIA ​​World Council meets in Tashkent, Republic of Uzbekistan, at the same time as the FIA's annual awards ceremony. Number questions The list of participants for the Guia Race Macau – Kumho FIA TCR World Tour Event of Macau had only seventeen of the twenty-four cars initially registered. This would have been one of the smallest starting grids ever for the highly popular Guia Race, whose first edition took place in 1972. In part, this number below expectations was due to the absence, for unknown reasons, of teams and drivers from TCR China, one of the strongest national tourism championships in the world. Meanwhile, Marcello Lotti said during the Grand Prix weekend that TCR is preparing to welcome a new brand to the championship. However, this announcement, scheduled for next Friday, is not expected to have an impact on the starting grids of the Kumho FIA TCR World Tour, as it will be a car group that already has a presence in the championship and will replace one of its brands with another. The Italian businessman also said he was in negotiations with a second brand. Asia's influence on today's biggest Touring Car championship is not just limited to the Koreans from Kumho and Hyundai, as the competition also features the Chinese brand Link & Co, at an official level, and the Japanese counterpart Honda. At a time when electric cars, SUVs and city cars are the focus of big brands, Asian manufacturers are still among the few that invest in cars, with fuel engines, with dimensions suitable for Touring events.

item.title: Taça GT Macau | Fuoco avenges the 2024 disaster and wins without a problem
item.description: The Italian driver finally managed to take the Ferrari to the highest place on the podium, and overtook Raffaele Marciello, the driver he collided with last year at Curva do Lisboa, when he was leading, and which earned him a retirement. Antonio Fuoco (Ferrari 296 GT3) was the winner of the Macau GT Cup, a race that he dominated from the beginning to the end. The Italian thus avenged last year's retirement, after being forced to retire, when he was leading, after a contact with Raffaele Marciello (BMW M4 GT3), at Curva do Lisboa. "I think it's very special to win in Macau, especially after what happened last year. But this is part of racing, and the main thing was to come back this year, and manage to do everything well", said Fuoco. "The team did everything for us to come back and win (…) I tried to make a strong start, and push hard in the last corner to open up an advantage over the rest. I pushed a lot and at a certain point I was losing control of the car in the Mandarin Curve, but everything went well", he said. Fuoco also praised the new qualifying format, with a second session only for the best qualified: “it was a lot of fun, I think it was a good change”, he considered. In second place was Raffaele Marciello, who had won last year, but who in this edition never showed the pace to threaten Ferrari's dominance. However, the Swiss was once again involved in collisions, this time with Alessio Picariello (Porsche 911 GT3 R), who ended up in the barriers. “I tried to recover at the beginning and I almost managed (…) but the Ferraris had a good start and it was a difficult race”, said the driver. “The car was very difficult to drive, so at a certain point I had to realize that the important thing was to reach the end”, he added. Porsche with different fortunes Porsche also secured a presence on the podium, through German Laurin Heinrich (Porsche 911 GT3 R). “I knew that starting from eighth place on the grid it would be very difficult to recover, but I think I benefited when I lost a position in the qualifying race, because that way I was on the most favorable side of the starting grid”, he reported. Heinrich also acknowledged that he did not have the pace to achieve more than the lowest place on the podium. "I tried to put pressure on Raffaele Marciello, but I felt there was no progress for him, so I knew I could only do better if he made a big mistake, which he didn't. The race went like this also to make sure there was no pressure from behind", he pointed out. Heinrich also regretted the touch on teammate Ayhancan Guven, which caused the Turk to be left out of the race: "On the one hand I'm happy with the podium, but I'm also sad about what happened. I think my colleague had a good pace and deserved more", he lamented. Despite racing in Macau with an Italian license, the Chinese driver was welcomed as a national hero and was one of the most sought after drivers in the paddock to take photographs and sign autographs. The driver even dreamed of victory, after starting from second place on the starting grid, but a less successful start meant he did not go beyond fifth place in the end. Nothing that would affect his popularity, given that after the race he continued to be the most sought after among fans.

item.title: Motorcycles | Todd crowned King of Guia after driving recital
item.description: After a year in which he was declared the winner without a race, Davey Todd showed that he is currently the fastest driver on the Guia Circuit, dominating throughout the weekend. In the end, he regretted not having set a new circuit record Davey Todd (BMW M1000RR) was the winner of the 57th edition of the Macau Motorcycle Grand Prix, on a weekend in which he did not give his competition any chance. After being declared the winner of last year's edition, without there being a race due to rain, the Englishman returned and removed all doubts about the fact that he is currently the fastest driver in the category. “It was a fantastic result,” said Todd, moments after the victory. "I knew I had a good pace, that I was strong, but that Peter was also going to be fast in the race. Fortunately, I managed to push from the start, gain a significant advantage in the first few laps, and in the end I just had to manage", he explained. As happened last year, rain once again interfered with the organization's plans and qualifying, which was originally scheduled for Friday morning, was moved to Saturday, right before the main race. Todd secured pole position and during the race he never let go of that place again, building a considerable advantage lap by lap, enough to cross the finish line in a wheelie. However, the winner regretted not having taken advantage of Saturday's high pace to set a new circuit record. "I think I'm disappointed with the fact that I was close to breaking the circuit record, but, during the race, I didn't know what times I was running. I was very close, so I could have beaten that record", he lamented. “But we are here to win the race, it is not to break records, so the most important thing has been achieved”, he stressed. In recovery In second place was four-time Macau winner Peter Hickman (BMW M1000RR), who had to deal with gear problems on the first lap. Recovering from a major accident, the Englishman started from third and took advantage of Erno Kostamo's (BMW M1000RR) mistake, who went ahead at Curva do Lisboa, taking the middle spot on the podium. In the end, Hickman acknowledged that he had a good pace, but was far from ideal shape: "I need to work more on my body, to gain endurance. At this point, I have the necessary strength, but I get tired quickly. I'll have to work in the winter", acknowledged Hickman. The driver also admitted that he was scared in the first laps by Erno Kostamo's driving. “To be honest I was a little scared with the way Erno was running, because he started with a really strong pace, but he was also making big mistakes,” revealed Hickman. "Luckily he didn't fall, because if he fell I would have fallen with him. This also allowed him to gain some advantage at the beginning", he acknowledged. “Then, when he went ahead at Curva do Lisboa, I managed to have a free track, and I managed to do my race”, he indicated. Happy running Mistakes aside, the Finn was one of the great entertainers of the race. He started from second place, lost position at the beginning and until the Hotel Lisboa curve, still on the first lap, he managed to regain it. Then, due to the error, he dropped to fifth place and in just over a lap he rose to third. Therefore, despite the incidents, Kostamo said he was happy with the result: "In three laps I pushed the pace a lot. It's true that I made a big mistake at Curva do Lisboa, when I missed the braking point, which was crazy", he reported. “But I’m happy with the result and for having set the fastest lap of the race,” he said.
